RATING: 7
There are certainly better games--and I feel like I graduated from Memoir '44 to Combat Commander, finishing my degree in WWII Hand Management Studies--but few things can compare to the joy of pushing around my little plastic army men and rolling my little dice with grenades on them.

Commands & Colours might be my favorite wargame system only for its having found a fun combat resolution system that involves rolling dice while neglecting the obnoxious need to add and subtract countless modifiers. 

As whole, Memoir '44 could really use some more meat on its bones, but it was my introduction to cardboard-based combat and its charming presentation and clever gameplay still hold a special place in my heart.

RATING: 4
[I]tl;dr - Command Cards ruin an otherwise enjoyable light wargame for me. I can't take the luck of the draw where an entire flank inexplicably can't move.[/I]
[COLOR=#CCCCFF]____________________________[/COLOR]

Memoir '44 looks really cool, but the command cards ruin it for me. Without a way to flush useless cards, an otherwise strong position can be totally wiped out. I'm quite skeptical of a wargame that's so dependent on luck of the draw. Additionally, two-player-only games don't really have a place in my collection unless my wife will play them with me, and this one is definitely not up her alley.

RATING: 7
Score is 8 by itself (not enough unit variation/chrome/replayability), 9.5 with the air-pack, campaign book and one more expansion (variation/chrome/replayability), and then dropped back to 8.5 (because a game should not force you to buy so many extras just to get its score higher).

This game often evokes the rather heated discussion on whether it is a wargame or not. 
Let me put it this way - before getting this game, my list consisted of mostly Euros (of which I am still very fond). After playing memoir (and expansions) I now own more than 50 wargame titles and have a few dozens more through various P500 systems at GMT/MMP/LNL/DG/etc. I would never have considered myself a wargamer and supported the hobby (both in finance and spirit) if it was not for this game. If you look around, you will find out that my story is not an isolated case. To me, there could be no higher accolade for a wargame than bringing scores more players to the hobby, and if this is what Memoir has done - then yes! THIS IS A - WAR - GAME! (spartan music in background)

Update: score dropped down a bit, only due to mostly been replaced by Memoir Online (its own worst enemy?), zero setup times, and ready opponents. Also f2f version been replaced by C&C:A.

2013/01
Still going strong and still a 10

2016-10-24
It is time I wrote more comprehensive comments here. Memoir '44 has been a game that has held its rating of 10 for years now. 

The first obvious reason for me loving Memoir '44 is that the game is easy to teach because the game mechanics and the theme support each other thus making the rules easy to remember. This also helps with decision making during the game. You can make valid decisions based on solely on your gut feeling. There is no need to go through complex equations to make a good decisions. Sometimes they might give you an edge but you can get close trusting your intuition only. However, at the same time the decisions you have to make are still meaningful and most of the time the best choice is not trivial.

My second reason for loving the game is that it plays fast in approx. 45-60mins a game, which is pretty darn good for such an action packed game. Of course, in such a short period of time you cannot even hope to grasp the desperation the armies experienced on the field during long campaigns, but I also think that you cannot get much closer in under an hour. Moreover the game has just the right amount of luck involved allowing for taking big and even bigger risks without making you feel that you are investing a considerable amount of time just to decide the winner by chance.

One point of criticism though. Despite being a modular allowing for countless of expansion and almost infinite variability, expanding the game from this base game is not necessarily a good idea. Personally I bought a considerable number of the available expansions in hopes of playing the game even more but what happened was exactly the opposite. The expansions introduced too many components to the game so that managing it all became very taxing. Furthermore, with the expansions you got many exceptions and rule breaking situations which were sometimes hard to remember because you were not using all the extra stuff all the time. Thus the game diverged from everything that made it great, i.e., from fast playing and simple yet meaningful to a slow handling but still a simple game. In other words, the game became unbalanced with regards to (weight x length) vs. (simplicity x luck) ratio.

So, my criticism is aimed more at the expansions than on the base game itself. It is true that after a point you kind start to wish there was more content in the the box but in my experience doing it does not make you happier.

My review of the game can be found here:
https://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/508722/maturing-review-memoir-44-after-50-plays

RATING: 9.5

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
In some ways, this is a difficult game for someone like me to rate.  I've played scores of "serious" wargames and how do balance those against something like this?  Not to worry - I think I can, by looking at the strengths and weaknesses that this has...and there are much more of the former than the latter.  For one thing, this is enormous fun.  

Other points are that the cards work really well and give a good feel for what it much have been to wait for orders in battle; the board and pieces are really well done; most of the scenarios are really close and to the wire; the game is easy to learn and quick to play; there's a great deal of replayability; and, I think it could encourage a lot of younger folks into more serious wargaming.  

The rules are obviously on the very easy side for anything you may attach the word "wargame" to, but I didn't see that as a problem in most situations because the balance was good.  The retreat rules did bother both myself and one of my playing partners a bit and we thought there was room for a few house rules on special armour, bunkers and standard infantry being caught by tanks in the open, or tanks being caught in forests (there is a rule for them firing in).  On the whole though, I wouldn't tinker too much with what is a good and fun game, but for the record, I've made a few simple tweaks, which SHOULDN'T be used all at once but a bit at a time.  Here they are:
http://www.boardgamegeek.com/thread/29501

I would say that this game is better than many "serious" wargames and I'd much prefer to play it than some of the really heavy stuff like Flat Top and Drang Nach Osten.  I wouldn't say that it was quite as good as the classics, which aren't that much more difficult and which have a great deal more tactical and strategic choice - games like Midway, AK, WSIM...well a fair few of the early Avalon Hill Games and the odd game from other makers, too.  However, I don't think it's that far behind these, and they are a different beast - this has to be classified as "a light wargame."  

On the weakness side, maybe it lacks a little depth for those who like to think hard about most moves...but again, most people who play this don't want that.  Nevertheless, for me, good though this is, I can't get it to 9 or 10 as a rating.  One more point- if you enjoy this, maybe you could try some of the old AH classics next.  They won't bite, but you may enjoy them!

RATING: 1
Dumb and pointless;  neither a fun game nor a wargame.  I thought my kids would learn a bit of history, and instead they called it "unrealistic"!  Commands & Colors: Ancients is far superior.

Or, put it this way:  M'44 is right up there with Mickey Mouse Yahtzee, which really doesn't give the latter it's due credit...

I wrote those words at least two years ago, and I stand by them.  What I've learned, though, is that as STOOPID as it is, Memoir is nevertheless fun to play if you look at it in the following way:  It's NOT a wargame, and has as much to do with war as little boys and their gren army men.

RATING: 8
Memoir '44 is the best introduction to wargaming out there. Nothing beats it when it comes to balance, simplicity, and even educational value (the Historical background for each mission is given in the scenario handbook). The game takes strategy, but put the Analysis Paralysis downtime behind with the card system. Player's only have 5-6 options per turn, but a whole deck of cards that are varied and interesting. My only two issues are the dice (sometimes one infantry unit can wipe out a whole tank unit so the randomization is still a little prevalent) and the set-up time is darn-near 30 mins. You can't even have a filler ready because it's only a 2-player game.

RATING: 8
My rating is for the base game.  The rating for the family is much higher.

Memoir 44 is a fun game, but should not be judged in a vacuum.  To really experience it, you need to try the expansions.  West front is a tiny part of the picture.  When you add in the Russians and their command deficiencies, the Japanese and their Bushido Code, the Gung Ho Marines, the great desert tank battles between Monty and Rommel, the air rules, and the numerous tiny bits of chrome (specialized units and weapons), you see just how good this game is.

But when you try the Overlord system (even for just 2 players) and the Breakthrough boards, and try the Campaign Books -- oh wow!  This game just keeps reinventing itself.

It's not a game without deficiencies: infantry is more successful against armor than it should be and artillery is too powerful, period.  These could be tweaked with house rules.  Also, the medal count encourages carnage more than objectives (unless you use the Campaign books).

It's way more game than history.  If you want a fun, simple, conflict game, pasted on to a WWII backdrop, that will play in an hour, this is for you.  Otherwise, look elsewhere.

RATING: 6
This looks like such a compelling game, and has some excellent ideas.  However, the card system dominates play too much: if you get a bad set of cards, you will lose.  If you end up with cards dominated by one flank, and need cards to do something on the other, there is no mechanism to allow me to swap cards, or substitute an action for another, which is infuriating during play.  Also, some of the special cards are seriously powerful and can affect the game balance dramatically.

I also don't think there are quite enough dice rolls to even out the odds.  A single set of dice rolls can have a big effect, particilarly in those scenarios that have relatively few units.

RATING: 8
(Own 2)

I am one of the many that rank "Memoir 44" highly as I love the simplicity of the rules, board and pieces. It's strengths lie in the relatively quick play time and the option to keep things simple while also allowing experienced players to add more rules and complexity in the subsequent packs that have been released. 

Those that don't like this game usually levy the criticism of "it's not a war game" which is fair enough but [i]is[/i] a game about war. Who cares if it doesn't have all of the stats and modifiers that other, more in depth war games have - this game shines because of it's accessibility.

The vast array of official and fan generated scenarios mean that there is plenty of replay-ability here. 

And finally, playing the game in the Overlord mode (I do it with 2 copies of the base game plus the Operation Overlord expansion pack) is a blast! I've tried it with 4 and while fun, the rule book clearly wants you to opt for 6 or even 8 instead as rules for 4 player games are not as clearly outlined. 

Excellent game!

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
Memoir '44 is a bit too simplistic to be a serious simulation. Although I was very enthousiast at first instance, my sympathy is dropping the more I play this game.

M44 is a fast playing game. A bit too fast to my taste, because I like my games double or triple this time. So complexities as optional rules could have been added and therefore more game depth. Now it is all too shallow.

I also criticize the card deck. It is always the same one deck, with cards that make no sense or appear at too random occasions. There are no optional cards per scenario for instance or deck building possibilities. Both players could then have their own deck and build own based on their strategy.

Furthermore I do not like the gameboard division into three areas, but I can live with it. It works well, but is quite artificial. The three wing division should be on the units themselves, so you could shift over the board. I also have strong doubts about game balance in many scenarios, which always end too abruptly.

My conclusion: far too simular to Battle Cry, Battlelore and others in this line. More a result of good marketing than game design.

RATING: 8
It's so easy to dismiss this as a stodgy old WWII war game. It's so not. The fact that it's made by Days of Wonder should be a big clue to this. Memoir 44 is an extremely fast playing tactical strategy game with a WWII theme that almost feels like a card game. It feels like a light game because it's so easy to learn, with simple mechanics that make it accessible to new gamers, but there is a very satisfactory amount of depth. There is quite a bit of luck involved, but it fits the theme and makes you feel more like a general dealing with the chaos of war. If you are typically adverse to war games, you should try this game out.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
I am sure this has been said this way before, but it is accurate, so I'll say it.  Memoir 44 is like playing an entertaining war movie, for all the good and bad of it.

It is paced just right for the balance it is designed with (luck, decisions, impact, etc).  The game design is very nice and tight for what it is.

--------

After more plays, I am more impressed than I thought I'd be.  First, the big negative, which I absorb later as a positive: the section freeze problem on bad draws.  This hurts, and feels settlers-dice broken, but I think you just have to think of it the right ways...

I like block games.  They have great fog of war.  They are also limited in auditing either untrustworthy opponents, or more often/likely mistake prone opponents (my kids, drunk friends, whatever).  The cards provide a fog of war element that does not take away the ability to audit.  Sure, the fog is slightly less effective than block games, but close enough, and worth the audit tradeoff.

So I now but card driven wargames more than I used to.  I 'get' the tradeoff in game design.

Another thing, a probably bigger thing, that I really like, is the orthogonal unit types.  This is possible due to the very high abstraction level, but the feel, at least at the war movie level, is still not abstract, in a good way.

Now I'll swing back to the negative that will keep this down at a 7, even though I think the system is capable of at least an 8.  The decision making and maneuver gameplay is pretty straightforward...the 'best' decision on a play is usually obvious, and the lookahead for plan is usually pretty short.  This is the one aspect that the other card driven wargame I like so far excels in: Manoeuvre.  The problem with Manoeuvre though is how the deck design is non orthogonal but detailed (not my taste), and drives odd gameplay to the point of losing suspended disbelief.  IOW, I think I actually prefer the CC system, which I did not expect to say.

So the answer?  Possibly CC Napoleonics, which has some combo mechanics and unit states that sound like they will drive longer lookahead and deeper decisions.

RATING: 8
A solid choice for an entry level war game. As a history fan, I really enjoy the theme. The game doesn't take long to learn, but that doesn't mean it is easy. Hand management is a key to the game because you have to correctly time your movements. If you run out of cards for a sector, it can leave you vulnerable to attack. The game remains tense throughout where often you can go from a feeling of defeat to victory will a well timed move.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 4.5
Edit:

Complete downgraded for this basic box. Read BASIC box.

Why? It was thanks to the PC on line version that I could play it "hardcore" (read many times) and I was in shock by the lack of lasting appeal ... due to the luck this game is all about.

DICE + CARDS + limited surface = a game with more than 80% based on luck = sadly not so good as I thought.

Curiously PC versions of board games will show the strong but also the WEAK points of a design.

And Memoir 44 falls short in the luck category. As a matter of fact it IS a complete turd as "an historical wargame".

While games like Small World and Ticket to Ride opened up extreme good gameplay features, Memoir44 falls flat on its face by playing it many times.

A pity since I collected all the expansions. What a waste of time and money...

Basic Mem 44 is not a historical simulation, it is much too much based on luck and it is crippled on limiting mechanics. 

The only good thing for the fans is the Campaign books I guess so you can ride some long term games with it. Not much historical wargames of course.

---------

Update Edit: I upped it to 4 now after having tried the new breakthrough mapboards. It is now starting to look like a light wargame at least, but it still is far from a WW2 simulation. I guess with all the latest expansions included (breakthrough/winter war/new miniatures/campaign books), a "6" is perhaps deserved, BUT the basic box still stays an ugly simulation and a broken game with a WW2 themed attached to it as an afterthought.

You can have LOTS and LOTS of better stuff with these 300 Euro's in expansions. Perhaps start with C&C Napoleonics for a better wargame from the same author. 

Memoir D-Day is of course the best of the series and I recently gave it 8.2. A pity you have to fork out tons of money before you can play it with XXXXXX expansions and new card rules...

RATING: 8
If you're not too tied up in recreating WW2 from a historical pov and want to get into WW2 strategy games then I strongly suggest Memoir 44. The base game (there are many expansions) mainly covers Overlord and Cobra. The scenarios are well designed to get you straight into the game and following a tried and tested (I think Squad Leader founded this type of learning scenarios) method each subsequent scenario builds additional complexity. Many of the scenarios are vastly unbalanced but the rules acknowledge this and suggest switching sides so that both sides can tally victory points (called medals) from a point of both strength and weakness.
I played this game with my brother-in-law who doesn't have a particularly strong attention span and he got the rules in short order.

RATING: 7
Great idea and I love most aspects of the components, but I find the game scale irksome, even while acknowledging this is a "light wargame" focused on speed and fun. 

Given the standard map size limits, I understand the design need to limit ranges, but it still sucks that the scale/range/speed relationships between inf - tanks - arty are so scrunched.  It's like taking a 256 level gray scale 8 bit image and normalizing it down to 4 bit 16 level -- you lose a lot in the transformation.

Also, pet rock, shot itself in the foot by making the baseline Germans dark blue instead of gray.  Duh????!!!   Given Mr. Borg's and the production company's usual insights, I would have thought Feldgrau would have been a no-brainer color choice.  Bugs me every time I set up the Germans, and contributes a good deal to limit my praise.

RATING: 9
When I was a little child one of my favourite games was battling with the toy soldiers: I had thousands of them, from the ancient Greeks and Romans to the World War I and II armies up to astronauts and spacefarers, all of them in the 1:72 scale. Then I grew up, dropped them but kept their fond memories in my heart: so, when I happened to play Memoir ‘44 for the first time, those memories resurfaced at once and made me discover how much I still love to play a boardgame displaying so many toy soldiers.

Of course many things have changed over these thirty years: Memoir ‘44 has rules, needs to be played with an opponent over a number of scenarios and requires some kind of strategy, while my childhood toying with plastic soldiers included just one rule, the rule of awesomeness. Yet there’s the same feeling and fun in Memoir ‘44 as I remember there was in those distant days.

I’ve written this foreword to tell in real terms how much I enjoyed playing Memoir ‘44 despite its historical background, a genre I’m not that crazy for: nonetheless, I found this game enthralling and, however easy to understand and handle, complex enough to appease even a demanding wargamer.
I can’t help but think though how much better it would be were it set in an imaginary or (science) fictional setting.

RATING: 8

Plays in 30 minutes.

RATING: 9
Only one play so far, so this may change, but I really, really enjoyed the game. We played the first scenario, Pegasus Bridge, and I just really appreciated how simple and quick it is to play. The ease of movement, checking range, and telling how many dice to use is very appealing- a war game without the massive commitment of time, expense and 'fiddliness' that comes with something like Warhammer. I even enjoyed the randomness of only being able to issue orders to units when you have cards that affect them, as well as the randomness of the dice rolls. It makes the game very low pressure, instead of a head to head, stressful death match. Hoping to play this more, and perhaps find something that's similar, but a bit more complex.

RATING: 5
This was my first try with the Command & Colors system.  It works well and makes a nice, light, war game.  I am heavily reminded of the old Battle Masters game, but now you have a choice on your turn instead of just flipping over the top card of the deck.

Remarkably, me being a Euro-gamer, I was able to thematically explain nuances of the game that my war-gamer friend didn't like, like why a flag can cause a loss and why a certain number of trophies can be considered a victory.  I would have thought it would be the other way around, where I would be the one questioning the thematic nuances.

The game is too light for me.  The dice play too heavily into the role of counteracting the solid strategy choices you feel you are making.

RATING: 8
This one is interesting.  Every time I suggest it I get a funny look from my gf.  However once we start playing she is the one cajoling me to set up another scenario, or to flip the board to play the other side just one more time.  It's almost as if she's ashamed to admit at first that she enjoys playing a game which on the surface seems so "boyish." The plastic army men do seem a little anti-female at first as far as a game they might enjoy.  Like I said though, I have a hard time getting this one off the table once it gets there.  Over time I think this stigma is starting to lose steam with her and she's finally succumbing to this games charms.  It's almost like a Euro in disguise.

Yes, this is a pretty simplistic view of war however I can't deny that it's an enjoyable experience.  And since I won't be getting my gf to play CC:Europe or ASL anytime soon, or ever for that matter, this fits in nicely for us.  And at least for the time being it satisfies my need for a WWII themed game.  Perhaps as my gaming circle of friends increases I will step up to beefier recreations of  this conflict and I will start to frown on this game, but for now I really enjoy getting Memoir onto the table.  I look forward to trying out some of the other Command & Colors games as well.  I think Battlelore will be a hit. And I thought getting her to play with plastic army men was tough.  Wait until I throw the plastic dwarfs, goblins, and giant spider on her.  Again, I will get "the look" and then we'll kill two to three hours without even knowing where the time went.

RATING: 7
Memoir '44 is awesome.  I've cooled on it a little since it first arrived, but not by a lot - we both enjoy this one very much.  Really, it's about as deep as I want a (non-Euro) war game to be.  I find some of the play gets dictated a bit too much by the cards (that is, some of the cards feel too powerful), but otherwise the system is a nice balance between control and chaos.  The bits are great, this is definitely a game you can get into, whichever side you are playing.  We really enjoy match play with this one (seems like the only fair way to do it, really).

I can see this game is going to be a money pit, though.  I've managed to snag the Eastern Front expansion and the Winter/Desert map through a math trade, and it adds even more goodness to the game - the Eastern battles are epic and make use of terrain in much more interesting ways than the early hedgerow slogs in the Western front.  I REALLY want the Campaign book, which basically lets you re-fight the war one battle at a time, with the outcome of each battle affecting the next.  I'm just waiting until I've acquired the necessary components (the Terrain pack, the Air pack, and the book) before we get going on this, which is also perhaps why I've cooled on this lately.  My only complaint (shared by many) is the set-up time required - expect to put in at least a solid 30 min getting the board ready.  It's well worth it, though.  Can Days of Wonder make a bad game?

RATING: 5
A little conflicted on this one after playing half-a-dozen times. Is it good and entertaining? Sure. But somehow it doesn't rise to the level of being at all engrossing like some of the better light wargames (Wizard Kings, for instance). For me, I don't agonize over choices, decisions are generally pretty obvious. Sometimes the flavor is good and it feels like a WWII game, sometimes it falls flat and you're just pushing around plastic - it depends a lot on the flow of the cards.

This is a decent enough game. It's fun, it's short, it's simple, there are lots of close games, and it's a lot better than any of the Axis & Allies games or Risk or Eagle games or most stuff in the "simple with lots of plastic" genre, if only because it's short. But it falls into the second tier for me, the "good stuff that I'm glad I bought but aren't exactly top tier and I'll probably sell eventually".

Memoir '44's predecessor, Battle Cry, had a bad entertainment vector for me. It was great for a half a dozen or so plays but crashed very, very rapidly after that. Memoir '44 hasn't entered that death spiral and I'm pretty sure it won't anytime soon, beacuse it's much more varied than Battle Cry. But for me, it's hard not to wish for a little more tension, a few more tough choices, that would punch it up over the top. As it is, a fun game - good especially for playing with kids - but for me probably not a classic.

Another comment is that some of the scenarios are really quite rediculously bad, which is not so good. Also, there is little to zero historical relevancy in the box aside from the blurbs introducing the scenarios. And what's with all the French scenarios? You'd think the liberation of France was mostly a French affair, and the British were some sort of bit player.

The Overlord format, while it sounds good in principle, is in my experience painfully bad. You've doubled the size of the game, but quadrupled the number of players, and Memoir '44 is a game that is already flirting with being boring at times. Halve your decision-making input, and it becomes a snoozer. 8-player Overlord is a party game, not a "real" game.

RATING: 7
I played Memoir '44 a ton when it first came out, and remained interested for a long time!  However, 7 years into the life of the game, and I find I'm a lot less excited than I used to be (Memoir '44 was a 10 for me at one point).

However, it's still a fun game that I'm happy to play!  The hand management aspect combined with the positioning of units is a pretty fun experience, and the multitude of scenarios ensures that every game is different.

The main drawback to me is the tedious set-up for each scenario.  The game plays rather quickly, but the set-up can be a real drag.

Other than that, a fun game that is amplified with great production values and a slew of expansions that add cool new twists to the game.  It's sure to remain a solid 2-player game in my collection for a long time to come.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6
Holy hell, this game is addictive.  See, I'm much better at tactics than strategy; I like war and historical atmosphere, but I don't actually know any history or have any interest in faithfully simulating it; and I'm great at picking up on games quickly, but just stupid enough to never actually "solve" them.  In short, this game is made for me.  Short play time + asymmetric starting positions & powers + pure unadulterated aggression + limited meaningful choice at any one time = 100% pure, uncut, Columbian awesome.  

That's not to say this is the perfect game.  Far from it, actually.  The gameplay is overly simplistic.  There are a limited number of troop types, movement and combat rules are basic and rather unrealistic/inexplicable, and the outcome of battles frequently turns on the luck of the card draw (which usually only let you activate troops on 1/3 of the board, whether you have troops there or not).  It's a short enough game, however, that you can fill an afternoon playing best 4/6 (3 scenarios played twice, alternating sides) in about the time it would take to get in a full game of Through the Ages.  

And these aren't flaws.  The game is still very fun.  It's just sort of unsatisfying.  It's like gorging yourself on halloween candy, or watching a marathon of Aqua Teen Hunger Force, or creating a Candyland variant/drinking game.  It's great enjoyment at the time, and hard to stop, but afterwards you feel a little...unfulfilled (and maybe a tad bit ashamed).  

Overall, it's a hard game to rate for the reasons stated above.  For someone looking to get into wargaming, it's a good start.  For someone who doesn't give a damn about strategic depth and just wants a game that's fun, it's perfect (kinda like Galaxy Trucker).  But there'll always be something gnawing at me after I'm done playing (conscience?), and I'm not sure just how much that will start to bother me with repeated plays.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
M'44 is a fun beer&pretzels entry-level wargame most suitable for kids, intergenerational gaming and adult gamers, who wish to take a break from more complex fare. Stunning components, short playing time, simple - yet expandable and highly customizable - rules and a reasonable portrayal of WWII warfare make this a fun and accessible gaming experience.

Having played both Battlecry and C&C: Ancients, I do feel M'44 is the most successful in the series. Battlecry's relatively bland, whereas Ancients - despite the greater complexity - doesn't IMO do as good a job portraying ancient battles as M'44 does in bringing WWII to the table. Why? My major beef with Ancients is that the critical weakness of flanks and the rear hardly are taken account of. Given the nature of modern warfare, this is no issue in M'44. 

Cards determine which options are open to you. The key here is to make the most of those (card) assets given to you. In 'simulation' terms, I believe your options being limited by the cards also makes enough sense. Lets assume you're a battalion commander. Not having any left flank section cards even though you want to order those units into battle might simply mean that your company commander in charge of that section of the front refuses to budge (a common occurrence in warfare) or communications with those troops have broken down. Similarly, not having say the air support tactical card, simply means that your superiors are denying you the requested air strike.I think such command issues provide greater realism than the traditional god-like powers allowing you to force each and every unit to engage in 24/7 combat.

Bottom line: This is one of my favorite games and I love playing it!

RATING: 8
I agonized between choosing this or Commands and Colors: Ancients. Ultimately chose M44 because I predicted my wife would be more inclined to play this version of the C&C system. Why? More attractive components, a more engaging theme for her, and a base game that contains a more manageable set of units and rules. 

I was right about pretty much everything but the theme. My wife found the WW2 theme unsettling, and consequently this is not getting much play. However, I'm still holding onto the game because I do enjoy it. With all the scenarios and setups, M44 is a very flexible game that plays quick, offers interesting decisions, with a dollop of luck of the dice.

M44 is also an excellent entry into the "commands and colors" system, as there are really only three different types of units. Any complexity is really via the different types of terrain. 

I'm afraid that if I get any frequent plays out of this game, it will be via the Overlord maps. Since I've lost my wife as a possible opponent in two-player-only games, I expect that the game that will hit the table more under those circumstances is instead Commands and Colors: Ancients.

Update: I had picked up some Overlord maps, but ultimately traded all that away because it simply wasn't getting any play. I'm still holding onto the base game. My C&C game of choice is Battlelore 2nd edition, but the sheer simplicity and approachability of this game makes me want to hang onto it... for now.

Update: Sold off the remaining M44 stuff. That's not an indictment of the game. I think it's a great game. I just concluded I have room for only one Commands and Colors game in my collection, and Battlelore 2nd edition was getting more play.

RATING: 6.5

The ergonomics of the game can be an issue however with opposing figurines that are too similar in color, don't fit in the hexes, and get to be a pain to wrangle.  In particular M'44 suffers relative to its Battle Cry/ CC:x sisters from the inclusion of "elite" unit markers that are added into the already crowded hexes.  Worst case, you have an elite panzer unit that has four tanks mashed into a hex and a marker teetering on top.

RATING: 9.5
GATEWAY WAR GAME!

Got my girlfriend playing this (having never played war games) and a month later we're sitting around playing Twilight Struggle and other heavy GMT games.

This game is wonderful!  Fantastic theme and respect for the subject matter; it's downright educational!  Game mechanics can be explained in 10 minutes and you're off.  I feel the dice and cards provide just enough luck to add tension to a solid strategy game.

The components are out of this world good for the price.  Two different boards, and a book full of scenarios to change it up.  Additionally, there are lots of other set ups available on the DoW website.

Also, it plays very quickly, which can lead to multiple scenarios in an evening.

Can't recommend this one enough!  I want the campaign book so bad!

RATING: 7
Memoir was a surprise. I'm not the biggest fan of WW2-based wargames, but SU&SD kept going on about how it was a great game for people who didn't typically like them. I found it used for a good price. The rules are easily digestible and try to simulate the chaos and unpredictability of war more than anything.

I don't think I could play this all the time, but I've enjoyed every time I've played it.

RATING: 9
Although one might say there is always room for improvement, in my humble opinion, I feel Memoir is about as close to perfect as you can get.  It accomplishes everything it sets out to, and does it well.  There is something here for everyone outside of perhaps the hardcore grognard.  Where else can you get history, action, basic strategy, card play, dice rolling, cool componentry, and just plain fun wrapped in a system that you can teach anyone in 5 minutes flat?  Plus, put it on the shelf for 2 years and you're playing again with just a brief review of the absolutely stellar rules manual.  Other companies should learn from Days of Wonder.  They hit the nail on the head with this one.  

One play and you'll be transported back to your youth playing army men in the back yard.  What more could you want out of a game?

RATING: 8
This game finds a good balance between strategy and luck, making it easy enough to pick up and play for any gamer. Die hard strategists won't dominate (due to drawing cards and dice rolls), while new comers (to strategy games or WW2 history) won't be lost under a tonne of finnicky rules. The mechanics for movement and combat are deceptively simple, and really smooth making the longest part of a given game setup and probably decision making. A game with this much replay ability, plus the sheer versatility of the rule mechanic means this game is great value for money, gameplay wise. Not to mention the components in the box are of a very high standard. My only two gripes would be the high price and low availability of expansions (most of which are worth it for what they add) and that occasionally the game seems unfairly weighted against the axis, though again more scenarios and my own ability might have contributed to that.

[i]Optional friendly house-rule: using any useless card to command a unit (from any section).[/i]
[i]My [color=red]Solitaire[/color] variant: for the "enemy" side, take only two cards. Select one and discard the other. Try to play the robot defensible, with all units in cover.[/i]

RATING: 7
Dec. 2, 2009 -- I've played the Pegasus Bridge scenario three times now, and while I wouldn't want Memoir '44 to be my primary means of war gaming, I can certainly appreciate the game's design and fun factor. It's not a simulation by any stretch of the imagination and some of the rules are pretty gamey, but for a filler war game, it's pretty good.

Sure, a bad hand of cards can guarantee a loss at times, but when a scenario can be completed in as little as half an hour, it's not a game-breaker. I'm looking forward to trying out the other scenarios on nights when I want a lighter war game. 7/10

Feb. 26, 2010 -- I've played Pegasus Bridge four times now and Sainte Mere-Eglise once. The scenarios are down to about 30-40 minutes of play time, which is a pretty good timeframe for the type of game Memoir '44 is. Good dice and good cards trump good tactics, so the game is a little too random for my liking. However, for a war game that plays so quickly, I can't really complain too much, especially since it's helping me to introduce wargaming to my girlfriend's oldest son. 7/10

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 3
Some time ago a friend of mine invited me over to play a game of Memoir '44. He knew that it was on my silent want-to-play list, and since he knew it fairly well, he offered me to play through a few scenarios. We were up and running in little time with the very first scenario, and I got a taste of the card-driven combat system.

I wish I could say I enjoyed the experience, for I'll be the first to admit that Memoir '44 does an admirable job of making a wargame subject accessible to a broad public. But I'm afraid I didn't really like the way in which the cards directed my options. In my case I had, for about two thirds of the time it took to play the game, 4 cards giving me movement options on a flank I had but a single unit on who would simply act as cannon fodder for my opponent were I to marshall him out of his hideout. If the game is about making do with what you're given, the designer should make it so that an excess of useless cards can be turned into an advantage elsewhere. Memoir '44 does not give me that option, meaning that I subsequently refuse to play from a de facto losing position. Losing because a player didn't combine his options as well as the superior opposition is fine. Losing because a player was held back by the game itself—even worse, a random card draw—is not. Now this was just a single game which probably represents something of an unlikely occurrence to begin with. So there's undoubtedly lots of opportunity to hone the skill of 'managing the randomness' in this title, meaning that over time, you will see that the more skilled player wins out over n00bs. But frankly, I can't be bothered with this pattern anymore. Too many games utilise this core idea already, and if I'm going to play a wargame I want to be able to have more control over my decisions in the first place.

I was nice to be able to try Memoir '44 in a relaxed setting, but I don't think I'll be asking for this game anytime soon again.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
Solid and enjoyable - if every wargame was this kind of easygoing fun, I'd be a convert!

Two players set up a scenario situation, each with their own victory condition, and chooses how to advance and attack based on cards drawn from a "command deck."  This clever mechanism forces players to focus attacks on various fronts and to move around the board as the cards dictate.  Victory points can also be scored by eliminating an enemy's unit, which keeps the game length to a reasonable time-frame.  The combat system involves dice and modifiers, but I found it to be less complicated than Arkham Horror.

Like all Days of Wonder releases, the components are strong and the rules well laid-out.  A good player aid is a must, however - check out the files section here on BGG.  On the whole this was an enjoyable game that I'd gladly play anytime.

RATING: 5

Falls under the category: I don't know why its popular.

RATING: 9
Plus expansions

This game has actually become an entire system now, thanks to the many expansions. Tracking down those expansions, however, will set you back a lot of money.

Base game out of the box is perfect for introducing new gamers, but will seem flat to more experienced gamers. Once you've added more stuff, you'll find a massive variety to enjoy the game: campaign, overlord, breakthrough, and the massive D-Day Landings.

What I really love about Memoir is that you don't have to memorize tons of rules thanks to the reference cards. Simply pull the cards specific to the scenario you're playing to refresh your memory, and then play.

Setup is a pain, though, due to the inconsistent layout of the double-sided terrain tiles.

RATING: 8.5

A word of warning:  If you have a little rugrat(s) running around (as I have) you'll probably have to spike that baby bottle before you set up a game. :)

The player with the most victory medals wins the game. Tought it to my son (8) who played along with ease, although the game is in English. Will defenitily play again :)

RATING: 7.5
In my mind, the peak of the Command & Colors system. There are some problems - scenario balance and historical accuracy issues being two of the biggest - but they are easy to overlook because the game is pure, simple fun to play.

Prefer this theme and level of balance over Battle Cry, and appreciate how Memoir doesn't try to take itself too seriously (Ancients) or spend more effort on production values than entertaining scenarios (BattleLore).

Expansions owned:
- Eastern Front

Certainly not as good a game as Commands and Colors: Ancients, but I prefer the time period and enjoy the tons of expansion bits that have added some neat chrome. I especially loved the Air Pack that not only added air rules but rewrote all the scenarios using the additional rules that had been added over the years. *Not even close* to a simulation, but usually exciting and always fun. 

Especially worth it for the Overlord games...if you can get eight people to play, those games are a blast.

Update: The breakthrough scenarios have given this a bit more life...the larger boards give some room to maneuver and make for more interesting battles.

RATING: 8
We have had a blast with this game. Whereas typically we are lucky to complete one ordinary wargame in a 3-6 hour session, we have knocked out 7 or 8 scenarios of M44 in that timespan. The action is intense and the card system translates into enormous replayability. The game also accommodates team play very nicely. The game is also very well suited for house rules and home-brewed scenarios.

On the downside, perhaps a bit more luck-dependent and "gamey" (as opposed to being a more detailed sim) than some wargamers might like, but that's not a major downside. 

In summary, a nice change of pace game and a good filler before and after a main gaming session. Go for it!

RATING: 10
I have played this game over 40 time in the one year that I have owned this. My girlfriend and I love this game and will play it for hour one end. This game has so much replay-ability its ridiculous! The base game come this 16 scenarios, which if you play both sides, offers AT LEAST 32 games even if you never play it again. Then there are all the official and unofficial scenarios available on to DoW website. There is a really great list on BGG that has all the official ones for all the expansions. I printed out all of these and have added an extra 15 to the base game alone. 

We love that this game is pretty portable. We play it at local  coffee shops and hookah bars that have pretty good sized tables. The best part of this game is that as long as the board fits the table, you should be fine. Might need an extra chair or a little extra space on the table for the deck and your extra pieces but they don't take us to much space.

RATING: 1
The single worst war game ever made.  Pure luck.  No strategy.  I don't care how much strategy you think you have, all the luck in this game will take it away.  If you are looking for a 100% war luck strategy(uh, scratch that last word) game, this is it.  You will see one troop take out 15 tanks and 15 troops with no return fire.  Yes, only THIS game can do that.  You could be down to your last troop and win this game.  You will NEVER find a game with this much luck.  It's like that crappy movie where the hero is getting his clocked cleaned the pulls out a magic weapon and wins.  The worst balance is the cards.  It's painful how bad they were thought out.   

Even though this game has been out for a while, there is no reason the following should not be fixed.
Fixes:
1) add return fire
2) balance the damn cards
3) remove all the MOVE ALL cards.
4) Attack dice should equal number of components in unit.  If you have 1 man left, you get 1 die - not the same as you did when you had full strength.

These simple things could make this tolerable. 

This game is not even good to teach kids as it would teach them bad ideas.  

If I could, I would give this a negative rating.
But as long as we all know this is a TOY that wasn't thought out too well, then a 1 is ok.

Beware - Battlelore, all Command and colors and now Westeros! All use the retarded system.  What a waste of money.  

Even poor villagers could shoot back in the real war (unless it's this war where they are waiting for card).  But in that case, those same villagers will take out your tanks with a pea shooter while you do wait for one.

 Does it make money?  Do people bet on craps?  So if you like games that are 150% luck with NO strategy, this is it.  I guaranty this prevents all strategy.  NO matter what you think you know about strategy, this retarded game will remove any chance of that.

So to summarize...I hate this game.  Are you getting this.....game...strongly dislike...bad...garlic...lighting too much.......I hate you mieces to pieces!

RATING: 9
I have tried to get into "real" wargames a few times and they never clicked for me. Then I tried "Memoir '44." This is a fast-moving "wargame for the rest of us." It has enough historical flavour to feel somewhat authentic, but it's just plain fun to play. Only criticism is that the set-up is a bit fiddly, but that's a reasonable trade-off for the modularity of the components. Luck plays a significant factor, but knowing how to manage your cards and making the best of what you've been dealt is a key to success. Now lusting after the expansions.

RATING: 7
I'm not a wargamer, but I love this game.  It is fun, it is exciting and it is full of suspense.  Yes, there is also a lot of luck involved, but the game is short enough, so that doesn't matter much and you just have to learn to adapt to adversity.  People usually say that the game is too light for a proper wargame, but I find that to be praise rather than criticism - I really cannot see myself playing three hour long, fiddly games, full of some complicated rules.  And this is the exact antithesis of that: relatively simple rules, short, action packed thriller.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
An enjoyable, although not without serious issues, simple introduction to wargaming. I'm not sure that the flank/centre/flank mechanic is right for the more modern battlefields of WWII - perhaps they could have gone with a card mix that emphasised the need for combined arms rather than coordinating wings of the battlefield.

It is also incredibly luck dependant and with two levels of 'luck' to boot - the dice and the cards. As a player you can still make good moves and bad moves, although the good moves you can make will be curtailed by the cards you have available. If you draw good cards the decisions really make themselves. Even if you make good moves the dice can completely decide the outcome.

Also, the shallow depth of the board gives the battles a linear feel that is suited to ancients warfare but not to the mobile nature of WWII. This has been somewhat rectified by the 'Breakthrough' expansion and that is the way I would prefer to play the game.

In the end even the Breakthough map did not redeem it enough and I have sold it all off.

RATING: 6
[Borg] I like it more than Battle Cry. Fun, easy to learn, and it includes super play aids for a quick start with new players.

It's a highly replayable 'system game' with tons of variable scenarios just like ASL, but is magnitudes simpler. So far the best intro wargame I've seen. 

A luck factor does exist, but the design certainly rewards good play. Exposing units when you don't have more cards for that area will get you punished, so you do that at your peril!
 
Expansions add more and more chrome-y details, but the complexity is still minimal. Finnsish ski troops, Russian commissars, minefields are all handled with ease. All are recommended for fleshing out the possibilities of the system. High payoff for these extras, lots of challenge and lots more mileage.
 
For the best version of this system go try Commands and Colors: Ancients

RATING: 10
I have had this for a while now, and I still like it quite a lot. Nowadays I mainly play it solo, and that's mainly because all of the immediate friends who I know who could play it are hard-line figure-based war-gamers, who play such games as Flames of War, DBA, DBM, etc. If you don't paint the figures, their not interested. I recently had a look through the ratings for this game, and I am pretty sure most of the lower ratings are from these same kinds of players: Gamers who really haven't figured out that Luck plays a strong part in pretty every war game you can name bar chess. And when luck IS included, it's all about the balance between "The Fortunes of War", and strategic control. It's a very fine line to walk in game design. If M44 only had the dice, it would gain a lot of converts, but I'm pretty sure it would lose just as many players who love it. The Card play involved in this game has great similarities to Robo Rally, in that, yes, you get a random selection of cards, but it is up to YOU to make the most of what you get. That's not to say that there is a way to win with EVERY hand that you get dealt. That would go against the metaphor that a loser will state at the end of any game they may play (" It's just the hand that I was dealt"). It's all about the balance between the choices that you make, versus whether you had Luck with you on that particular day. A lot of games just forget that sometimes it just isn't your day. Yes, sometimes the Bear gets you...

RATING: 5
I'm not a pure Euro gamer, but find that I tend to like Euro style games more then pure Amerithrash. I enjoy some direct conflict but not as much in games where that is the primary focus. May bump this up with more plays, but right now I prefer Summoner Wars as I like the theme better, special powers and the movement restriction, that is, in Summoner Wars you have a choice as to what units to move (up to three units up to two spaces) where in Memoir movement is restricted to the luck of the card draw. One could argue there's more strategy in managing your hand in Memoir, but, as of now I don't find that as enjoyable. Further, many of Memoir's scenarios are unbalanced... while it's recommended to play 2 games, one on each side, still... not sure why I would want to play a scenario when it's heavily slanted one way or the other.

RATING: 7
A solid, simplified wargame. What I like most is the ability to play a complete game in about an hour. The rules are deep enough without becoming tedious like so many hardcore wargames. The varied scenarios included in the box also keep the game fresh - lots of replay value here. Throw in a few expansions and you could be playing Memoir '44 for years!

Revised for 2012: Almost 2 years later, I have to drop my score from an 8 to maybe a 7. It was fun while it lasted, but this title rarely makes it to the game table anymore. The scenarios just aren't as deep as I would like. I favor more complex wargames these days.

RATING: 9
An impressive Euro-game styled war game.  It is based on the same game system as Battle Cry, but improves it.  Battlelore is also based on the same game system, but adds a fantasy theme, lore cards, and focuses more on melee, whereas I prefer the ranged combat and historical theme of Memoir 44.  Having played through several of the first few scenarios, my initial impressions are very positive.  Despite having a considerable luck element (both in card draw and dice rolling), Memoir 44 allows enough room for decision making and strategy, and the toy factor helps make it buckets of fun, and appealing to a variety of ages.  A big thumbs up!

Odds of an Allied victory for the standard Memoir '44 scenarios:
69% - 1. Pegasus Bridge
63% - 2. Sainte Mère-Église
46% - 3. Sword Beach 
66% - 4. Pointe-du-Hoc
19% - 5. Omaha Beach: First Assault Wave
41% - 6. Mont Mouchet 
35% - 7. Vassieux, Vercors 
52% - 8. Operation Cobra
39% - 9. Operation Lüttich: Counterattack on Mortain
67% - 10. Toulon (Mediterranean front)
75% - 11. Liberation of Paris 
54% - 12. Montélimar (Mediterranean front)
80% - 13. Arnhem Bridge 
65% - 14. Arracourt 
45% - 15. St-Vith, Ardennes
47% - 16. Saverne Gap, Vosges 
Win/loss percentages taken from Memoir 44 Online statistics (May 2015)

RATING: 2
I’m not sure what this game is, but it’s not a wargame, at least not a game about WWII -- and yet … I totally get the allure of it. Let me explain. 

The way the rules work as an attempt at simulating command and control leads to absurd situations. Furthermore, the nature of the victory conditions is such that the map is rendered irrelevant. Sure, the hexes have terrain relevance when rolling dice, but you’re not playing the map in any realistic way, you’re just moving units and chucking dice to see who can get more hits before the other guy and end the match immediately regardless of the position of your forces. 

The result is more often than not something completely unrealistic and ahistorical. I’ve played my share of games f-t-f as well as the Days of Wonder app and in every single Normandy game, the Germans have brought units down onto the beach. Something ridiculous like that happens in every game, like one desperately broken unit forging ahead deep into enemy lines so they can pick off the last enemy unit for victory – as if they could suddenly call “time out!” on the battlefield. It’s one thing to have these ridiculous medals for victory conditions but the sudden death nature of how they’re enacted forces players to play a race for dice odds positioning not anything resembling actual battlefield tactics. The only resemblance to WWII are the army men you play with, but it could be rethemed and the experience would not change. 

And yet I get why this game is so damn popular. Managing a hand of cards and seeing if you can get the right card at the right time has a certain appeal. I'm not immune to the allure of seeing what cards I got and what surprises I can spring on my opponent. But in truth, it's easy to figure which card to play each turn (rarely not glaringly obvious) so there's little thought about what you should do, and then the dice take care of the rest anyway. 

The result is a low-stress wargame experience with a low rules overhead; ersatz decisions perfect for the casual gamer. Throw in some detailed figures, terrain, and a bunch of expansions for different theaters, and you’ve got a cash cow built on absurdity. It's the Olive Garden of wargames. 

Kudos, I guess?

RATING: 6
I'm changing my rating from 7 to 6, having played this today. I have to be honest, it's just not my sort of game. It's a wargame and I'm not a wargamer.*** I'm not a wargamer and my rating reflects this. We played the opening scenario only, and I really enjoyed it, winning as the Germans. It is a dice-roller, it helps if you draw the right cards, but as a Wargame-Lite, Memoir 44 works. Quick set-up, very quick play, an open and flexible system that I found a challenge simply as a puzzle. The mechanism for variable victory conditions is brilliant. I can easily see now why this is a hit game, it would seem to reflect the dynamics of WW2 encounters. No doubt we'll see Japanese and Russian fronts released soon.

RATING: 7
What's the big deal here people?!?  Combat is very much like Axis&Allies, the figurines are a little awkward to move around, units somehow retain their complete firepower despite depletion, the cards for both sides come from the same deck meaning that a player could luck out on the better cards and make for a quick one-sided trouncing (granted there were a few of those historically, but where's the excitement?), game play is rather bland and the tactics is dictated by the cards you're holding.  I do not understand the fuss and hype at all.
Update: tried the new terrain features and somehow the game gelled a little better than during my first impression.  Ok, I'll give it another try.

RATING: 8
[thing=14105]C&C:Ancients[/thing] might be the better game overall, but Memoir '44 has its advantages: it plays more quickly, it makes better use of the terrain, and I love the theme.  My wife tried it again not long ago and enjoyed it.  Most of my friends play as well, so it's not too tough to get an Overlord game together every once in a while. 

Rating is for the base game out of the box. My favorite scenarios tend to be those with unusual terrain, special units, special rules and all that mumbo jumbo. So with all of the different expansions, it's an easy 10. You don't need any expansions to get started with the game, but if you insist, start with the Army Packs: just pick whichever one is most interesting to you.

My recorded plays are only for scenarios published with the base game, or scenarios published later that only require the base game. All other plays are recorded under the expansion the scenario was published with.

RATING: 7
Fun and light and WW II.  The popularity of this game makes me think there's a niche for more entry level wargames that people can get into in half an hour.  I made a miniatures version of the game on a big board with 3-D hills, trees, towns and 1/72nd scale tanks and I'm surprised at how much I enjoy Memoir 44 as a set of miniature rules.  It really is fast fun and gives you a chance to use the terrain in clever ways.  I prefer the rules set of C&C Ancients buy enjoy the landscape layouts of Memoir.  If you don't buy it expecting a deep wargame it's good.

RATING: 4
[Dice rolling for combat, Random card draws for commands, World War II, Kid's Game] [2P:4, 8P Overlord:4] Okay, so it's Battle Cry with a WWII theme. How is it better than BC? Some of the mechanics have changed to accomodate the change of military eras, enhancing the flavor of the game, but it's not superior to BC. It's tactical-level simplified lightweight abstract combat in WWII. Works for some, but not for me. Great bits from DoW as usual, but since WWII-era toy figures are common, it's not as visually stunning as some of DoW's other work. Some Geek will doubtlessly go on and paint the figures just like Battle Cry. You can see it coming: rating is the same as Battle Cry - '4' for a nice, simple distraction with no depth and very limited replay value. Don't play more than one game at a time, or it becomes *really* annoying...
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7.5
PROS:
Historical theme, WWII
Miniatures and cool missions, even for just the base game. 
A good balance of risk taking, strategy and luck.
Fairly easy to teach, and perfect play-time. It never feels like it drags and it's pretty rare that the battles have a clear cut winner until the last turn or two.
Fairly easy to teach.

CONS:
Takes a long time to set up compared to the length of time it takes to play (about 10 minutes to set up, 30 minutes to play).
The Command Cards (you know you saw that coming) can really hurt you sometimes. It is really frustrating when you pretty much start the game with a bad hand and continue that bad luck through-out the game.

RATING: 8
The most abstract of the 3 C&C games (still in print). Normally that would cause my rating to go down slightly on a wargame but the game plays so cleanly I forget that I'm totally skipping major parts of most WWII wargames because I get so sucked into picking options. The scenario support of Memoir is head and shoulders above BattleLore! and unlike GMTs expansions of C&C:A the cost of the M'44 expansions is a little easier on the pocketbook. My only negative comment - the unit pieces are juvenille in what is otherwise a big boys game. I know I'm in the minority but I would have preferred blocks instead of little green army men. Even though its not my favorite C&C game I think it is the best overall.

RATING: 9
Great light wargame - simple, well-designed system that can be learned quickly, with most scenarios taking less than an hour to play, but complex enough to hold one's interest for a LOT of playing.  The command card system integrates some Euro-game type aspects, and introduces some randomness as well as time-saving constraints on player choices.  Non-wargamers are much less likely to be overwhelmed by this game since they don't have to consider all the possible moves, just the ones that their command cards permit.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10

Thanks to Memoir online my knowledge of the game grew and it has become one of my personal favorites, and few 10 ratings.

Memoir is a blast to play, is deeper than it appears, and fills the need for a quick but not vacant war game. It also looks spectacular.

I love it!!!!!

RATING: 8
My son was intensely interested in this game from the age of 6, thanks to a few mentions on the Dice Tower and some browsing of a Days of Wonder catalog that came with Ticket to Ride.

The WWII theme kept it on the back burner for me until he was old enough to discuss some of the concepts of the war before playing with its tropes.  He started pushing for it some more after his 8th birthday, so I finally bit the hook and I'm glad I did.  He and I have played this together quite a bit and really enjoyed it.

It's a little light for me, personally.  I expect that I'd enjoy some of the other C&C systems a little more.  But I'd never trade the time I spent playing this with my kid, so I'll probably never trade the game either. I know that's a fallacy, but I'm sentimental.

A classic in our house.

RATING: 4.5
A good game with a big problem- the game compounds balance issues to the point where at least half the games you play will be frustrating. Individual scenarios are (deliberately) unbalanced, the command deck can give one side killer hands that make the game a blowout, and the dice are rolled just seldom enough that they don't seem to even out the probability if you're having a bad game. That being said, the system is fun and tense, despite its problems, and it's satisfying to move the beautiful pieces around.

RATING: 7
Acquired September 2006. 

(As of November 2006) I have played this only a few times, but the popularity of the game is easy to understand. I think it is almost amazing that a war-themed game can be played so quickly and be so much fun. It cannot be considered a "true wargame," since it only superficially re-creates actual events. Card draws and dice rolls determine most of your options and success, but it's still a fun game, especially for "old wargamers" who no longer have the time or opportunity to play the "real simulations."

May 2009 -- I haven't played this game in several years, but would be willing to do so again.

RATING: 6
A very light hex wargame that is a good intro to newbies to hex wargames, it isn't very deep, the scenarios aren't very realistic, I personally don't like the little models and much rather a more informative cardboard chit.  But to a newbie the models would seem more approachable, thats for sure.  The board and pieces are beautifully crafted.

Its card driven and I really don't think the card contents add to the realism and makes the whole game a little too gamey.  The left/right/center command activation mechanic seems rather strange for a WWII game and seem more suitable for a pre-radio era game where communication laterally across the battlefield may have been an issue.  Despite all this, it is suppose to be light and in the right mood, it makes for the perfect wargame.

RATING: 7
Ok (very) light wargame - just 3 troop types, no morale system, scenario based - but it works well and the simple mechanics provide quick and fun game play.

There is a significant luck factor in both the draw of command cards and the luck of the combat dice - if both are against you, you are gone big time! - but the game plays quickly so just turn the board around and play again. No hidden information other than your opponents command cards exacerbates the extreme luck swings

All the bits are excellent.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.1
Elegant design. It's the kind of rulebook that you read and go "ahhh, that's clever" every few sentences. The cards are excellent, the idea that a random hand dictated your only available actions (for a wargame!) originally put me off, but I quickly realized that the cards work really well.

The simplified design sometimes shoots itself in the foot, but the quick playtime encourages 'just another game' so it's not a massive failed investment if you have an uneven game.

But the design that sometimes proves frustrating is also the game's greatest strength: by only allowing the moves printed on the cards, the game completely eliminates any trace of analysis paralysis, but maintains a thrilling combination of overall strategy and tactics.

The fact that you still feel in complete control, even with limited card choices, is impressive. This game is fantastic, it really is.

RATING: 8

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.5
Memoir 44 was the first tactical war game that I played. The game is easy to learn and rules are explained very well in the manual.

The time frame for the original scenarios is 1944, a period during which the german army was slowly pushed back towards Germany, so the game is a bit more difficult to win with the german side.

The game has a few strong points:

1. Setup is easy. Just place the tiles and troops on the map according to the scenario and that's it.
2. Learning time is low.
3. A very simple battle system.
4. This game is fast. Depending on the scenario and your luck with dices you can finish a map in one hour or less.

Of course there are things that could have been done better. Gun miniatures look fragile, normal armor units can barely be squeezed into a hex, terrain tiles are very easy to move if you are not careful.

Anyway winning of losing I had fun playing this game, so it still gets table time.

RATING: 8
Very impressed.  I liked Battle Cry, but there were many annoyances and imbalances, prompting me to introduce several tweaks and rules fixes.  The problems included: the edge of the world phenomenon when retreating, too many unusable cards, no way to cycle cards, the overpowered All-Out Offensive card, and the underpowered Skirmish and Sharp Shooter cards.  Well guess what?  Memoir '44 has fixed **every single one** of these problems!  I also like the faster pace and greater maneuverability (appropriate for WWII), the new rules for close assault, and the greater variety and balance in the card mix.  Most importantly, I feel like I have important choices to make while playing Memoir '44 - something that didn't always happen in Battle Cry, where the more restrictive cards and lack of manueverability often forced me down very specific paths.  All in all, I've never seen anything better in the super-lightweight wargame category.

For reference, I rate Battle Cry 7/10 and C&C Ancients 10/10.  I lowered my rating of Memoir '44 from 9 to 8 after C&C Ancients was released.  I still enjoy playing Memoir '44, but the meatier C&C Ancients is the most satisfying game in the series.

RATING: 10
Hard-core wargamers probably scoff at its simplicity, but that's what makes it such a great game. Memoir '44 doesn't try to be anything but what it is: a fast-playing, exciting, easy to learn wargame with superb components and interesting gameplay options. A true winner from Days of Wonder.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 10
I bought this game to play with my brother. It is one of the best two-player games out there. Yes, it's a war game, but it's very light on rules and mechanics. Otherwise, the theme of WWII battles is wonderfully recreated here with scenarios from actual battles, and the ability to create your own. The game incorporates cards to perform your actions, and creates a fantastic bluffing game because the cards only let you move and take actions on either your left flank, right flank, or in the center of the board. You could bring all of your units into one section and watch gleefully as your opponent beats a hasty retreat thinking you're going to wipe him out on the next turn, while in actuality, you don't have a single card that lets you move those units again. Fun, addictive, and a great introduction to more advanced board games, MEMOIR '44 is a masterful creation of theme, mechanics, and components.

RATING: 5
Initial rating of 6

Traded away my copy as I just couldn't see myself really WANTING to play this. Should someone else bring a copy and want to throw down I suppose I would.

I would rather play any of the other Commands and Colors offerings before this.

Q: All of the Commands and Colors games (Battle Cry, BattleLore and CC Ancients) are the same core system, right?

A: Yes.

Q: So why play the other ones and not this?

A: Well, Mem 44 is just too light for me when it comes down to WWII. I came up playing much heavier games on this subject and I like more detail than Mem 44 provides. That and I just cant help feel that the game mechanics were forced to cover WWII, they just don't feel quite right for the time period, however, the core mechanics of this series feels correct for the other themes.

This and the fact that all units have the ability for ranged combat really makes the playing area feel too small for the rules.

Fix - Allow players to use any two Activation cards of other areas to activate units of the desired area, use the value of only the lower/equal of the two cards played, the second card is discarded, then draw two cards to refill hand.

RATING: 8
UPDATE Battles of Khalkhin-Gol expansion has renewed my interest in this still very enjoyable game.

UPDATE AFTER 300 PLAYS: This game really needs the rather obvious house rule that if you cannot order any troops with the cards you have, you can order one unit of your choice. I will not play without it. 

UPDATE: Play it regularly online and Hellfire Pass and other scenarios are still brilliant online. Wish Winter Wars would come online soon.

UPDATE: Online version in beta 25 is a 10. No need to set up terrain, sound effects and opponents from all over the world! Love it.

UPDATE: M44 Breakthrough with Winter Wars rules (For example, Probe 2 allows movement with 2 units who can fight, plus 2 units who can just move), really makes the game shine. The biggest drawback with M44 is now removed. I´ll try this rule with Commands & Colours Ancients. 

UPDATE: Memoir 44 Online Beta is wonderful.Bring on Eastern Front!

Remains one of my most played games. The accessability is hard to beat. I was a bit burned out after over 50 plays. But the Air War expansion saved it. Played 23 of the Scenarios from the Front on the Days of Wonder homepage. Stonne 1940, Third Battle of Kharkov, Operation Lightfoot and the Battle for Smolensk are great examples. The users have introduced new house rules that improve the game.

Update:  The scenarios all sort of suck.  The way the artillery works doesn't make any sense.    Still love the bits though, and its still pretty fun.  It works really well as an intro to C&C:A, otherwise I would probably trade it.  Its shaken out as a pretty mediocre game.  The lack of battleback is a huge problem.  Your units are getting mauled in close combat, but they don't hit back?  The tank and artillery rules also make little sense.  This system, which I love, just doesn't work well at all for WWII.

I ended up trading this away in a math trade.  I have C&C:A, which fills this niche much better.

-Degrading strength
-Battling back when melee
And is therefore the superior game imo. Nevertheless, the easy Memoir system and quick turns make it THE ideal introduction game for newbees and younger players.

RATING: 8
A "light" wargame which can be appreciated by grognards and beginners alike.

Played with 2, 3, 4, 5 and 6 players (using a single copy of the game).  Also tried with 8 players using two copies of the game.  It was quite enjoyable, regardless of the number of players, as downtime is kept to a minimum.

Rulebook, mapboard, soft plastic units, counters and terrain tiles are of excellent quality (artilery pieces are a little thin).

Doublesided mounted mapboard with (2) isomorphic sides which allows for expansion of the battlefield by combining multiple copies of the game.

Game requires 10-15 minutes setup time (terrain tile and unit placement).  Use of a Plexiglas to hold the tiles in place is recommended, but not necessary.

Card holders are a GREAT addition, as I used these with other card games!!  :)

Card activation system minimizes "down time" and lends itself well to team play (players commanding one or more sectors of the battlefield --> Left/Center/Right).

Combat is resolved using special combat dice (8 are provided).  One seldom rolls more than 4 dice, so no dicefest here.

Game comes with 16 scenarios, each playable in 30-60 minutes.  Quick playing time allows for "round robin" type play.

Excellent game support offered via web site (here too!) as well as excellent customer service from Days of Wonder!

I liked the game and support so much I picked up a second copy!

[u]Expansions released in Oct. 2005[/u]: Eastern Front | Terrain Pack | Winter/Desert Map

RATING: 10
[center][size=6][COLOR=#878787]LIFETIME GAME [microbadge=28495]:star:[microbadge=28496] "PLAY FOREVER"[/COLOR][/size][/center]

Gets me in a way that [GAMEID=551] could not, as I lack the American Civil War gene.  The game engine is excellent—a beer-n-pretzels wargame for those of us who are not hardcore wargamers.

UPDATE:  Yeah, it's just playin' with plastic army men.  But sometimes that's all you need.
[floatleft][center][imageid=1339002 small]
[size=13][b]Not so much milsim[/size]
[size=15]as [COLOR=#FF0000][i]BAM[/i][/COLOR] & [COLOR=#FF0000][i]BLANG![/i][/COLOR][/b][/size][/floatleft][/center]
UP-UPDATE:  As I close in on 40 plays I suppose I must bump this to a 9; my interest is only accelerating and as a game system there is just so much to love here.  And while it might seem like a "heavily-themed abstract" the sheer number of units, options, and scenarios makes every game unique.

Almost every scenario is wildly imbalanced (a nod to history), making any single play unsatisfying for someone; but when you consider a single match to be two games with the victor having the highest total medal count after playing both the favorite and the underdog, well, then the experience is very satisfying indeed.  As the favorite you want to run that steamroller to victory as quickly as possible and minimize the underdog's score; as the underdog you want to simply last as long as possible and rack up as many medals as you can before you're snuffed.  On the odd occasion when the underdog actually [i]wins[/i]?  Then it's time to dance around the table and flick infantry units at the loser.

Hand management, probability, and the sequencing of attacks are all neat puzzles that keep each turn interesting, even when you're the one getting pounded.  And the whole time the setup just looks gorgeous.

There are more scenarios than I can probably get through in a lifetime... though I'll give it my best shot!

UP-UP-UPDATE:  It's a 10, earned the hard way—through ever-increasing game-pleasure.  The best scenarios from the expansions are engaging puzzles that not only bear repeat play, but unfold before you into larger and larger possibility spaces the more experience you get with them.  Some feel as if you could play them endlessly without ever becoming bored*—the static setup is a puzzle that requires a dynamic solution, depending wholly on the interaction between how the cards come out, hedging dice probabilities, and your creativity in manipulating it all.  Grinding the same scenario over and over is less about finding the optimal path (and solving it for all time) than it is about finding the way through the unique iteration right in front of you, right now.

Cards, dice, plastic army men, a historical veneer and functionally infinite replayability—this is very nearly the perfect game.

[size=7]*Yes, I know this isn't true—but the subjective sensation of infinite fun propels me onward.  Besides, should I be so lucky as to actually "wear one out" there are only a couple hundred more to dig into...[/size]
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

UPDATE:  The 2006 "Made in China" edition is a significant step down in production quality after the 2004 "Made in Germany" one.

:soblue:  The box has a cheap, plasticky finish instead of a nice linen one.

:soblue:  The printing on the cards, board and tiles is washed out and less distinct.

Looks like everything's cheaper in China, and it shows.

UP-UPDATE:  While I rate M'44 a 10 overall, this edition gets a 7 for production "values".
