RATING: 8
First Expansions to buy:
Eastern Front, Terrain Pack, Campaign Book 1 (all that is needed to do all the campaigns)

Second Expansions to buy:
Pacific Theater, Mediterranean Theater, desert/winter board

Third expansion to buy
Campaign Book 2 

Fourth:
Overlord (maybe this one sooner, depends on if additional expansions are need beyond what I already have)

Can get new scenarios for Days of Wonder website.

Get the Army Expansions first (Eastern Front, Pacific Theator ,Med Front in that order)

Maybe get Winter/Desert board with first army expansion.  Purely cosmetic.

Campaign Books after the army expansions.

Overlord is great for 6 players.  Can be done with 2 base games or the expansion.  Expansion has a slick deck of cards to make it easier to play but has tokens instead of figures for units.

Not sure about Breakthrough.  Need more info.

Terrain pack only good for making your own scenarios.

Equipment pack sounds unnecessary.

D-Day Landings sounds awesome but you'll need a ton of expansions for enough figures.  Not sure just how many.

RATING: 9

With expansions, which are nearly all great, there is a myriad of scenarios from all theatres of the war available, enough to keep you going for years.

RATING: 8
   Got my first play in this past weekend and followed it up with two more. I had high expectations for this game and since A&A is what I compare all to especially war games I came away with positives and negatives
   Negatives, played the first two scenarios and Yes my play partners are children so we did play the child rules so I expect that will add something. But the cards you have dictate what you do and where. If I really want to focus on the right but my cards dictate otherwise well? I think that is a reason I've never been much of a fan of card based games. That's really the only negative, yes the board isn't very big but getting the other games and expansions does solve that and being so new for me it's not yet and issue just see eventually I will want bigger. Ahh also limited units though first two scenarios only use two different.
    Positives, you can finish games in fairly short amount of time one game was after school something I wouldn't dare do with A&A. So a lot more scenarios to play plus the code I got to get more online should be good for awhile. Using terrain towns sandbags, bar wire and such certainly adds something and makes you decide besides just moving and shooting, you have to consider those options offensively and defensively.

RATING: 10
My favourite game. Richard Borg has achieved superb synergy between theme and gameplay in this light war-game classic. I love how the tactics selection combines with managing unpredictability in battle order card draw and the dice based combat. The movable terrain and other features (bunkers, barbed wire etc) really help evoke the differing historical battles. It is great fun, thought provoking and plays with remarkable efficiency. An awesome experience, even when losing! For me, Memoir ’44 perfectly encapsulates the magic of board-gaming.

RATING: 9
What started out as a relatively simple World War II game using Richard Borg's Command and Colors system has evolved into a remarkably deep experience. The fighting system is still simple and will never win any realism contests, but the depth of scenarios available (especially if you have expansions) makes this a fantastic game for me.

RATING: 8
Blimey, a wargame with (gasp) HEXAGONS ON THE BOARD that is attractive, fun and quick to play! I played a lot of old AH/SPI kex and counter games in days gone by, and I'm impressed with the way this captures a lot of the flavour of those games without the anal rules systems and complicated charts. I've heard people grumble that it's not as 'realistic' as the old school games, although how you can say any game using dice and bits of cardboard can be a realistic simulation of taking a bullet in the chest is beyond me. I think the varying unit capabilities are modelled here very well, just in a more abstract (but intuitive) way than old school classics such as Squad Leader. Biggest luck element is probably in the card draw - there's a trade off between jumping quickly and finding you're in the open and don't have the cards you need and waiting for the perfect hand before commiting - by which time your opponent could have built up a strong position. Grognards may find it light, but to me  it's a deserved success.

RATING: 9
Wow. I have Command and Colors Ancients and consider that incredible. The production value in Memoir is beyond top notch. The cards are colorful, well illustrated, easy to read. The terrain cards have all the information needed to easily understand what they do. The pieces themselves are plastic and well done. The card holders are a nice touch. Better then CCA wood block card holders. The dice are nice to look at, but too light, I like heavier dies. The only drawback to this game is the set up time. Lots of terrain, lots of pieces on the board. The game is incredibly fast and beyond super fun. A game system that lends to many, many expansions. I guess I will eventually have them all. Lots of scenarios availiable. A near perfect game. Now do I buy the Battlelore and Battle Cry that are part of the Command and Colors line? My eleven year old son, actually setted up the first scenario. I thought he was just playing with the pieces, but he said "Dad you want to be Germans or Americans?". Wow. Even as I sit here typing my son has already setted up Operation Cobra behind me. See you later.

RATING: 8
Rating is an 8 with ~20 plays (including the Eastern Front expansion). Memoir '44 is a fast-paced game of tactical combat featuring 16 different historical scenarios between the Axis and Allies forces. The game uses dice and features a random card draw (same deck for both players), and the luck can go against you quite conspicuously in both areas. Additionally, the scenarios themselves are often obviously skewed in favor of one side or the other. I don't mind any of this. In fact, I think it's great fun when units "give 'em hell" (unexpected good role) or fail miserably (unexpected bad role). I also think it's a thrilling challenge to begin the scenario outnumbered or in a slightly worse position. Even with the luck, good tactics usually win the day, or at least give players the satisfaction of making their opponent pay for their victory. Memoir '44 is a game I enjoy playing well, win or lose. It's also fast and has TONS of replayability. 

Lately I've discovered C&C:A, which outshines M44 in many ways. Commands and Colors features a good deal more strategic depth, greater unit variety, a more suitable theme, and better components (I'll take blocks over plastic any day). It does all this without sacrificing any sense of flow. M44 paved the way for me though. 

Update: Memoir '44 is about Terrain and Ranged Combat. C&C: Ancients is about formations and close-combat. Very different feel to both. I have five boxes of C&C on my shelf an no desire to start up another multi-box investment, but M44 is great fun.

[b]My thoughts on Memoir '44[/b]
Memoir '44 is a scenario based World War II themed game with dice rolling and card play. It is probably one of the lightest games with a war theme on the market, with a high production value and a lot of variety offered through expansions and online scenarios. I've got a love/hate relationship with the left-middle-right battle areas and the restrictions the cards provide. 
Therefore, I only like the occasional game, and whenever I play I enjoy it. Sometimes I feel that the game is too random for its own good, but on the other hand, I think experience and smart play increases the odds of winning.
I'm not sure that I like the point based victory conditions. This game could really do with a bit more mission based victory conditions, but otherwise it is a good system that provides a lot of light fun play.

[b]Star ranking[/b]
Fun: :star::star::star::star::nostar:
Satisfaction: :star::star::star::nostar::nostar: 
Esthetics: :star::star::star::star::star:
Replayability: :star::star::star::star::nostar: Obviously gets better with the expansions, which I owned but traded away. For me just the base game is enough.
[b]Verdict: Not essential, might go at some point.[/b]
---------------------------------------

RATING: 5
While a big fan of Battle Cry, I've found this game fails to have the same "drama" as its predecessor.  Our games seem to thrive on rolling one die at a time to chip away at the enemy, due to the reduced firepower and greater amount of terrain.  The latter also has the effect of reducing the amount of maneuver, since the maps we've played have channeled the armor severely.

Playing through the Pacific and Eastern Front expansions improved my opinion of the series.  Raised the original game a point to reflect the play value of the expansions.

RATING: 8
Popcorn Wargaming! I now have played M44, Battle Cry and CC:A from the Commands & Colors series. I enjoy the series more from game to game. M44 might very likely be the best from this series as it plays the closest to the core as I perceive it: fast accessible wargaming with high replay value and lots of theme. While CC:A offers more strategic potential, it can drag a bit - plus for M44. The luck factor in M44 is high but with 30 minutes for a scenario once the game is set up it doesn't bother me and I'm not sure if there is much less luck in CC:A in the end. It's just not as obvious. First of the series to get 8/10.

RATING: 8
I like this game very much because my wife likes to play with me.  Cool historical aspect boosts the theme a bit.  Fun to play, with decent strategic depth, not necessarily something you need to think too hard over.  I really like the art on this title as well.

Edit - just played an incredibly fun and tense mission on Sword Beach.  The narrative in this particular game was fantastic, starting with allies taking a bloody beating trying to get onto the beach then the tide turning in favor of the allies once my artillery was softened and finally eliminated.  At the end of the game, with VP tied at 4-4, Allied is one order away from winning the game by taking an unprotected city/medal.  Axis has no orders in that flank, playing the medic card out of deparation.  A good roll replaced one unit and allowed that unit to be ordered to move and protect the town.  Allied special forces move in for close combat and eliminate another axis soldier from the unit protecting the town.  Attrition is not an option for axis.  Axis plays close assault, rolls 4 infantry hits, eliminating the unit and eeking out a win.  For this good time, Im re-rating from a 7 to an 8.  YEs, some luck was involved, but man was it exciting and it gave us a fun story.  Cant wait to play again.

RATING: 5
Memoir '44 has pretty much all of the features that added up to make Battle Cry a faintly ridiculous experience: dicey randomness, wildly divergent card power (a player who draws assault cards and the like will demolish a player who doesn't), absurdly gamey tactics (such as infantry charging out of fortifications), critical threshold effects, arbitrary and anticlimactic scenario endings, and a general lack of verisimilitude. What M44 has going for it seems to be variety, expandability, and possibly a better match between theme and mechanics. Commands & Colors: Ancients has some of these features as well but for the most part they are much mitigated.

RATING: 3
An entry-level game about war at a tactical level.

I'm not at all sure that anyone who likes this game would like a "real" wargame. It involves too much dice rolling, the cards are artificially restrictive, and the game offers very little in the way of the thinking needed for, say, Squad Leader. And yes, I know that's not a fair comparison. It's like saying a MacDonald's hamburger offers very little in the way of a Michelin 4-star meal. Besides, five or six pages of rules isn't going to give a game with the richness of a game with ten times as many rules. But for me, like a Big Mac just isn't worth eating, Memoir '44 just isn't worth playing.

In most circumstances, that is. Maybe in a hospital it would be a good game to spend an hour over.

RATING: N/A
I have been playing this lately on Steam.  I played it once on the table at BGG con 2014, and we thought it was totally stupid and put it back.  Then out of boredom one night I tried it on Steam.  I have come to appreciate it and it is really fun to play.  At first, the cards seem stupid because you can usually only play units in one third of the board, but when I think about it, it makes perfect sense, since in my mind, war is complete chaos: communications get disrupted, field commanders get killed, supply lines you need to keep the ammo and food flowing get distrupted, etc.  So despite your desire to run the entire show, you have snags to overcome and you only get to play bits and pieces of the campaign one at a time.  Quite simply brilliant and thematic, IMHO. Well, I have been fighting the Nazi war machine for several scenarios and I am really liking this game.  The online version through Steam has really cool sound effects for the different actions you can take, too.  Nice job, D.o.W!! :)

RATING: 7.7
- 2 player
- Weight: Medium
- Genre: War/Dice/Campaign
- Length: Long

This WWII game comes with cool miniatures, high quality tiles, and a bunch of historical campaigns you play through. Each game is different and comes with a small description of the actual battle that happened in history that you'll be re-enacting on the board. It's an asymmetric game, meaning one player has a different objective and methods of play than the opposing player so you play each scenario twice and see who did the best overall. Luck of the dice and cards prevent the game from being too one-sided against new players but the game still has plenty of strategy. Lots of replayability and with the right expansions you can even make your own scenarios with ease.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Well thought out game.

Many people have cried out too much luck.  There are 2 factors here, the Command Cards, and the Dice rolls.

The Dice each have 2 Infantry Hits, 1 Armor Hit, 1 Wildcard Hit, 1 Miss, 1 Surrender Flag.  To me it represents the fact that Infantry are easier to hurt (3:6 chance) and armor is harder (2:6 Chance).  This dice system works very well for me, and I like the unpredictability, the dice rolls seem to be consistent to me with the ratios given, which some bad/good rolls to give you a scare from time to time.

As for the cards, you draw 'em, you gotta learn how to use them to your best advantage.  I found myself screwed every now and then because the scenario had all my units in the center, and I wasn't drawing any Center Order cards.  I assume it's meant to simulate bad lines of communication, but I didn't like the feeling of not being able to do ANYTHING and if I wanted to play a real war game I'd go for Europe Engulfed.  I think you should be able to use a card to atleast order 1 unit if unable to use it otherwise.  For that I had to deduct .5 point. If anyone has any suggestions, do tell. (maybe I will learn to like this feature as I learn to use it against my opponent, who after all, has to deal with the same situation; this is a good article on this subject http://www.boardgamegeek.com/article/42307 )

Other than that, the board was beautiful, the pieces look great (except for the artillery, which were flimsy), and I love the modular board.

The rule book was very colorful and helpful, full of examples.

I know you can get a scenario editor, and can't wait to try other's when I'm done with the given ones.

*I've painted my units, giving them a black primer undercoat, and then painting over with a green and blue metallic color to bring out the miniature's detail.  Believe me, this requires no skill and is worth it.

RATING: 7
A Command & Colors game, sibling to Battle Cry, using basically the same game system (tweaked for the WWII setting).  Command cards do a good job of representing the fog of war and communication problems in combat.  The game is fast; can be fun; but doesn't have a lot of depth. Still, it is well supported with many expansions and third party scenarios; an online scenario editor and online play.

I think I'm in the minority here, but I don't really like the "Overlord" scenarios. More (players) is not always better. 

On the other hand, I think the "Breakthrough" expansion with bigger boards and larger scenarios is a good idea.

Began playing Memoir '44 Online 6/11/2011.

RATING: 9
Very luck dependent, but the first light wargame that everyone of our gaming group does enjoy. And that´s really worth it. But beware: You should be able to accept, that there might be very unrealistic and frustrating situations. We saw one artillery piece resist over seven game rounds (!) the attacks of three infantry units and one tank unit - with the result of three units destroyed, the artillery still intact. Another time three tank units tried overruns against infantry groups and were ALL eliminated because they hit nothing but the other player rolled grenades over grenades... Beside this, it is a great game we always enjoy :)

1. It is easy to play.
2. Every one in our game group likes it (wether he is into WW2 gaming or not).
3. Sessions are short enough to play some consecutive game rounds, so bad luck can turn into a win the next time.

Memoir 44 has a lot of what I expect in a wargame : strategy and tactics of course, but also "friction", this murphyesque (or clausewitzesque) feature that can make your best plans go wrong ("They didn't get the order in time") or desperate situations see the end of the tunnel ("Reinforcements are here !"). So in this respect the card deck is a great engine, because there is a real difference between what you see and want to do as a player, and what officers see on the field, what they can do. Of course it can lead to frustration sometimes ("come on left flank, move !") but with very simple rules it conveys command and control difficulties, fear, misunderstood orders, intercepted estafettes, etc.
Plus it is very simple, modular and above all, fun.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7.5
[Original] This is a fun and easy WWII wargame without the heavy aftertaste of an old school wargame. Although serious grognards might scoff at its simplicity, it is wargame truly designed for the masses. Does it perfectly reflect the intricacies of unit combat? No. Does it simplify unit combat into an easily approachable form? Absolutely. Each turn is quick and flows rapidly from one player to the other. One minor gripe is that, even new, some of the tiny plastic units have slightly bent gun-barrels and stand off kilter (but then again, whose plastic, green army men ever stayed is pristine condition?). The rulebook is light and easy to digest; you can even download it from the Days of Wonder website. Take a look, and I'll see you on the beaches...

[2006.Dec.14] Despite the recent release of BattleLore, Memoir '44 continues to fill a wargaming niche that is ever-so-subtly different from that filled by its newer, sibling game. And as usual, I'm always eagerly anticipating my next M'44 game.

[2011.Mar.15] Got a chance (finally!) to play this again. It's still the same fun, beer-n-pretzels game that I remember it to be. I'm glad that it's in my collection.

[2014.Jun.14] Fun game. No doubt about it. The biggest drawback: set-up and clean-up. Still want to play though.

RATING: 8
I can get a little bored on a couple of occasions, during a game, probably because the game seem to often reach a similar state: you have units scattered on the board, and the obvious strategy is to attack the weakest ones, which involves a serious amount of luck. A game of Race for the Galaxy is so much richer: the situations obviously evolves in a qualitative way (your tableau grows).  Same thing for Agricola (new animals, new occupations, new family members come along during the game).  Even Go, despite the fact that it has only one kind of "units" (stones), which don't move, creates a board situation that constantly evolves.

As combats progress, tension zones are created.  This gives me a feeling similar to playing Yinsh or Schotten-Totten.  However, I find that there is are fewer tension zones in M'44 than in these two games, in a given session; Yinsh and Schotten-Totten having a much shorter playing time than M'44, this makes them more tense.

Also, compared to LotR: TMG (Combat Hex), I found that the combats are more generic: they always involve only one type of indistinct unit (infantry). I find LotR: TMG more epic, thanks to the different unit types (archers, spear men, heroes and all their distinctive special powers).  I like its nicer looking figures, its special powers, its more individual figures, its simple rules, etc. It gives me more of a "combat"/brawl/clash feel than M'44.

When playing solo, I prefer to play Conflict of Heroes: Awaskening the Bear.  In fact, the action-reaction mechanism of CoH keeps me more interested and focused than the more gamey IGOUGO system of M'44.  However, I did not find playing the first scenario of CoH face-to-face very rich.  Plus, CoH's rules are much more complex, and easier to forget.

The rules are rich enough for me, and almost too complex (i.e., not streamlined enough): terrain rules, obstacle rules, LoS rules, etc. In fact, I had to check the rulebook a few times. I also had to check the FAQ (all the answers were clearly spelled there!).

I found it more interesting than C&C:A, because I was able to concentrate on the game more. I seriously thought about chaining my order cards, about encircling the enemy, etc.

I like the fact that probabilities are quite easy to approximate: it is possible to make meaningful decisions.

I find M'44 better than LotR: TMG at forcing the players to adopt longer term strategies (efficient chaining of order cards, assessment of the emergencies with respect to the cards in hand, usefulness of keeping units in all sections while reacting to important situations on the board, etc.).

I also like deciphering what sections the opponent could act in. This is a useful facet of the game, that allows for some risk taking.

The variety of terrain and obstacles was a nice change from C&C:A.

I like playing against the AI, though, because I lose all the time (in 5 to 10 games), because I can invest as much time as I want in thinking, and because games last for about 30 minutes.  My repeated losses show that I have a lot to learn, which makes the game interestingly challenging.  In fact, making a whole plan around the hand dealt is not that obvious.  I also enjoy the challenge of getting a clear picture of the situation on the board (what zones are weak, important, etc.) and of its evolution during a game.  Knowing when to retreat, combining infantry and armor in a sound way are also interesting.

RATING: 10
This is a very easy to learn war game that isn't bogged down in excessive rules.  The components are detailed and the card art is spot-on. There is a luck factor with the cards.  While you get to choose the orders you are issuing to your army, your choices are bound to the cards you draw. Still, strategy plays a role. My only real complaint is how difficult it is to "re-write history." In other words, of all the times I've played, whoever won the real life battle in WWII, turned out to be the winner in the board game as well. For instance, if you're playing a campaign as the Germans and they lost that battle in reality, chances are you are going to lose that game. It can put a damper on things going into a new game. 

UPDATE

Since that writing, I have won as the Germans in the Battle of Normandy and once as the Allies in another scenario that actually had the Germans winning in real life.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
I had played many all night sessions of [GAMEID=181] and [GAMEID=98] as a kid, so in the back of my mind I was itching to try a newly updated wargame.  [GAMEID=10630] cropped up as a perfect, light wargame that was newbie friendly.  Plus, it was produced by Days of Wonder, which had a good track record with us for making very attractive games.  Even better, my girlfriend was receptive to trying it out as well.

As promised, the game was a beauty to look at and the modular terrain tiles could be used to make almost any map you could think of.  Unfortunately, the game just didn't work for us.  Most of our games ended up with our units hiding in terrain and sniping at each other.  There didn't really feel like any grand tactical formations that we could try.  We always had enough cards to play so that we could do anything we wanted in any section of the board, so there wasn't enough tenseness in the hand management, cardplay area either.  Most of the missions could be completed simply by destroying units---it would have been much more interesting if there had been more goals to focus on.  To be fair, we only tried the first few several missions, so perhaps things got better later on.

Fundamentally, it may be that we particularly enjoy games where we're actively building things up, whether it's train routes, cities, etc., rather than just attacking each other and tearing things down.  On the other hand, we just might not have liked the actual gameplay of just sniping each other and rolling dice.  For example, we liked [GAMEID=15363] (which has a basic resource/economic component to it) and [GAMEID=23375] (which had CCG card play for combat) better.

RATING: 6
Initial impressions: My rating might go up in the future for more unique scenarios and scenarios with different unit types. The basic concepts of this game are very simple: play a card, move your units, attack based on range, try to capture certain locations or wipe out enemy units. Some of the added stuff for the different terrain makes the game both thematic and fiddly, both during set up and in the actual game play. I think from this game I've come to realize I really like war games in theory, not so sure about the execution yet; sometimes I'd prefer balance over historic accuarcy. Because you play both sides in Memoir 44 it doesn't matter too much if one side is significantly weaker, but what I don't like about this game is how swingy it can be, both via clutch card draws and die rolls. For example, I lost 4-0 while playing the Axis because my air raid and one of my other attacks both missed on 50% attacks. Meanwhile when I played as Allies I only won 4-3, but that was because my opponent's air raid did succeed, and also my slightly higher than 50% chance bombardment failed, giving my opponent time to retreat his depleted armies and set up sandbags. Now considering I lost it's definitely more likely than not my opponent played better than me, but scoreline could have been wildly different if a couple of die rolls had landed my way instead.

EDIT: The different units do change up the game quite a bit and each scenario feels pretty different, but I think I'm keeping the rating a 6 because the game can still be really swingy.

RATING: 8
AWESOME GAME!  Just about the best 2-player game I know of.  Luck plays a part, but tactics are very important.  The fun factor is really high on this one.  Some have complained that luck plays too large a part in this game, but in my experience, that is not the case.

This is a game about managing your command cards and your forces.  The replayability is high because you can't always use the same strategy in a scenario.  Depending on the cards you draw, you may have to try to win the scenario using a different strategy.  Short and long-term planning become essential.  There is a lot of meat to this game, yet the rules are so simple (especially for a wargame).

RATING: 10
If they'd had this when I was a kid, I might be a wargamer instead of a euroguy and sometime ATer.  The system is genius, and the production values are fantastic.  The flexibility and customization are immense virtues.  Maybe above all, in terms of the scenarios that come with the game, I'm amazed with how balanced it is, even and especially with asymmetric forces.  Every game feels close.  And by the end, when you can see where the armies have broken through and where they've held their ground, you're apprehending a visual story like few games provide.  A masterpiece, fully deserving of every kudo.

RATING: 6
This game looks so great on a cursory inspection. The idea of a modular board to represent a bunch of different small battles that took place over the course of D-Day is terrific, and the simplicity of the rules  is attractive to anyone who likes the idea of wargames, but gets fed up having to stack chits and go through 50-phase turns. Plus, who doesn't love messing around with little green army men?

The game's a disappointment though. The rules are simply too dumbed-down, leaving players with zero strategic and minimal tactical options. And the decisions you do end up making don't feel anything like the kinds of things you'd be deliberating about in real life military conflicts.

Quick gameplay, but it's still a wargame. As such, I don't think that it will get enough use to warrant purchasing. However, the mechanic rocks so much!! Despite this, it would be worth buying if the price was $20. At the end of the day, I think Small World will scratch the itch for a similar game.

GREAT IDEA: Borrow the game once a month from Avi and see if the game is as well received as I would hope it to be.

Good kid's oriented introduction: http://boardgamegeek.com/video/8009/memoir-44/perfect-for-family-play-as-well-the-board-game-f


NB: The game has a high "want" factor due to its respectable game ranking on the geek. However, in thinking about how the one or two games have been played, the gameplay (i.e., with cards) leaves a positive impression, but the execution (i.e., rules v-v attacks on hexes at various distances) leaves  a negative memory of how the game was. As such, the game is definitely NOT one of our Want Very Badly games.

I think that Small World would scratch the Memoir 44 itch without having to go through (a) the typical war theme and (b) the resolving of conflict through targeting specific units and rolling dice. In other words, SW would probably be a little bit simpler in this regard and more fun.
NB: Small World focuses on area control vs. combat. This, in part, makes it more fun (and a "light" war-type game).

RATING: 10
This is my favorite game.  I even own unopened second copies of be base game and almost ever expansion in case something happens to the original.

I own dozens of WWII-themed strategy games (Squad Leader and so forth), but this is my favorite by far, and this is the one game I'd take on the desert island with me.

It captures strategy, history, tactics, and is all tactile and quick to teach and highly visual and varied.  Two of my daughters even love playing it in person and also online when with me when I'm out of town.    

This is a wonderful system and the online game is tremendously done.   It has both a solitaire mode and a great online mode.  A second version can also be played on Vassal with hundreds of scenarios.

There is also a terrain editor where you can create your own scenario and play on line or print out and use with the the boardgames version.  

This is the only "addictive" game I've ever played.

RATING: 5
I really am conflicted with this game.

Overall it is a lot of fun to play, and there are many scenarios, expacks, and flexibility with the components. And those are all things I really do love about this game. But the thing that really sours me on it is the nearly complete reliance on luck.

Cards & dice rolls...you will live or die by them.

Still fun to be sure, and there is some mild strategy involved. The problem with the strategy is that it becomes less about the battle tactics and devolves into "how do I not feed my opponent victory points". Many of the scenarios are focused on a set VP limit, and dead units count towards that goal...so as I stated above, eventually you throw battle plans out the window and just try to keep vulnerable units out of harms way.

I will continue to mix in plays where I can, and maybe even buy another expack or two just because it is fun, but it just never scratches that "war" itch.

RATING: 6
Good game - my only recommendation is to toss out the cards/sectors mechanic. Me and my friends play it this way:

1.) The second player, determined by the rulebook, gets to move 2 units forward as scouts. These may seize terrain, but may NOT engage the enemy.
2.) The first player, determined by rulebook, moves 50% of their forces forward, in response to "rumors of enemy movement in the area of operations." These may seize terrain AND may attack the enemy. 
3.) Second player then gets to move a full force attack, each unit marching/attacking as per normal. From then on, both players move each unit they control as if they possessed a card that allows all sectors to move all units. Without cards, we recognize no special abilities (Artillery Bombard, Air Strike, Armor Assault, etc.)

Expansions I own:
8/10 - Breakthrough Map
7/10 - Terrain Pack
7/10 - Equipment Pack
4/10 - D-Day Pack
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 7
A pretty lightweight game but the rules are so simple and the play so fast that the trade-off in terms of time spent to entertainment gained is huge. There's more depth and more of a wargame going on here than you might realise - just like proper tactical WW2 combat, it's all about best use of terrain for your unit composition. RATING: 6.06
Rating:

Game quality: The mechanics still seem OK and leave me wondering why I can't do certain things even though logic says I should be able to, ie my guys are standing right next to the enemy, but I can't attack them since I ordered units somewhere else to do stuff. 

The C&C system appears to create strategy and tactics through restriction versus more of a free form style system. I prefer systems that get out of my way and let me do what I want to. The system feels incredibly close to being awesome and yet...

Lowered score from 7 to 6 after a win oddly enough. Luck of the draw will play a factor at some point in a tight game regardless of strategy.

After 5 plays I lowered it to a 5. Seems stuck there. I want to love it, but I don't.

Update: After time away from the game and a 6th play, things finally clicked for me. I still don't love the card system, but I think it works for what it is trying to do in a gateway system. The lack of you being able to use your cards in the end can simulate just how tight resources are at the end of a battle.

It can be fiddly to set up.

I can't think of anything wrong with the dice system but something feels off.

There's still better versions of the system even when I originally played the game and now there is BattleLore 2nd edition which I think really fires what is left of this game since it includes miniatures, which was one advantage the game had over other versions of the system. If you are picking Memoir '44, it is for the theme. 6

Would I buy this again if I was starting over: I don't own it. I know someone who does and there is online play which handles the fiddly parts of the game. Considering I think there are also better C&C systems(just about all of them really), I can't come up with a reason to own it. If I want WWII, I got Band of Brothers or there is the Conflict of Heroes games. 0.

Do I want to play this if asked: I'll play if asked, but I'm not asking to play it. I'll enjoy it enough to bump it just above a 5. 6.

Overall: 6.06.

Rating Potential: Likely stuck as is. I think its greatest crime is that it was one of the earliest games in the C&C system. Give this game a BattleLore 2nd edition treatment and it could get bumped to a possible 8+.

RATING: 8.5
This game is excellent. The base game is great - with any of the expansions it's even better! The single best expansion to get for Memoir is the Air Pack as it adds planes as well as a full set of cards outlining the rules for all the other expansions.

The comment about the time to set up the game is a fair one. There are a number of elements to set up before you can play but I find that after finishing one scenario you can quickly set up for another (you'll rarely just play one scenario!).

Gameplay is simple and depth of strategy is good. Yes - you will get unlucky with your card draws and dice rolls but this is a strategy-light game. If you want something more realistic there are other games out there with instruction books as thick as your wrist.

I would definitely recommend this game to people who like the theme and have someone consistently to play against. The base game is great but is much improved by the various expansions.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.5
Command & Colours. A neat system. In itself straight-forward and elegant. In the Memoir '44 version, though, it is complicated with special rules for different unit types, terrain and faction specialities. The C&C system in its core is elegant and disregarding the dice almost Euro-ish, but in this version it is definitely fully an Ameritrash game. That said it is still a neat system of playfully representing a WWII light wargame. 

Against the game, though, it the extreme reliance on luck. All attacks are dice ("colours"). And the options of the player depends on luck of the draw from the "command" deck. Wargames relies to an extent on luck for good reasons; to simulate the winds of war. But Memoir '44 is founded on luck to an extent that makes it sometimes frustrating and annoying. In some ways M44 is like Warhammer 40000 played on hexes and with cards telling which units to activate. When rolling this amount of dice a game should be fast and a laugh. However, M44 is rather an investment in time and frustrated tears. 

I recently played a large 180 minute campaign where an certain victory because of good placement and solid tactics was turned into an embarrassing defeat because of two cards played by the opponent and the game was won on literately one dice at the end. Some people might find that fun, perhaps even epically so, however I found it incredibly anti-climactic and it gave me a very bad taste of the game.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8
The Command and Colors system, overall, is a 7: It's lighter than I prefer, the movement, range and combat values are often wonky and the realism is...amusing. It is a very light wargame, lighter than air, in fact. But it does what it sets out to do and does it exceptionally well. Taken on its own terms, as a [i]game [/i]--not a simulation--it passes the most important test: It's fun. Memoir gets a boost to 8, because I'm a WWII guy. Ancients is not a particular interest, but it has a bit of added complexity that keeps it at 7. Battle Cry (both versions) and Napoleonics simply aren't a period of interest for me, so they are a 6.

Memoir specifics:
I was uncertain about this game, but with several plays under my belt I must say that I like it. With five plays now, I like it a lot. Enough that I've bought several expansions.

I advise you to ignore the folks who dismiss it as not a wargame, not a simulation, or whatever. It's a light wargame that does a nice job of abstracting the chaos of warfare. And it looks great doing it.

Setup time is on the longish side, but not as bad as I feared, and not as bad as BattleLore. But the payoff is a clean, easy to learn game that is just fun. It's not a deep simulation, but it doesn't pretend to be, and unlike a deep simulation, you can play several battles in a single night.

I think it does a nice job of balancing luck and skill, and above all it is playable. You have to make good choices and manage your hand, but it really helps to get a little lucky. There are a few cards that are quite powerful if used wisely in the right circumstance. You might not have the right cards and get hosed, but this makes you be flexible and creative. You don't have complete control of your forces, which is okay in a light game like this--and it's a pretty successful way of abstracting the chaos, disorganization and imperfect performance of military units in the heat of battle.

Good stuff, and I hope to play this many more times. It could easily move up to a 9. I doubt that it could be a 10 for me, because this is not my preferred level of depth and simulation, but this is not a design flaw.

Appreciate this game for what it is: fun.

Other things that might bother you about this game: the units (with minor exceptions) are generic; the ranges are a little off; and the victory conditions encourage gamey maneuvers at the end. But [i]at this level [/i]of abstraction, I don't see why they should bother you much, unless you're just itching to find something wrong with the game.

RATING: 7
[size=10][u][i][b]r{Initial Thoughts}r (after 5 plays):[/u][/b][/i][/size]
* One of the best light introductions to the wargaming genre
* "Play a card, draw a card" mechanic is easy to teach and quick to learn
* Tons of scenarios, both official and fan-made, allow for excellent replay value
* Best played with players switching sides in a total medal count series
* Collection completists may break the bank trying to hunt down all the expansions
* Good for budding wargamers and fans of light CDWs (Card Driven Wargame)
* Initial rating: [b]8/10[/b]

[size=10][u][i][b]b{Further Thoughts}b (after 25 plays):[/u][/b][/i][/size]
* Very little 2 player gaming opportunities have decreased plays
* Gaming tastes seem to have drifted away from this, but a renaissance could occur
* Online implementation through DoW is excellent, but restrictive because of fee
* Further rating: [b]7/10[/b]

[size=10][u][i][b]g{Advanced Thoughts}g (after 50 plays):[/u][/b][/i][/size]
* The renaissance hoped for above has come, in the form of my young son
* Great for re-exploring with a young gamer, and to teach basic strategy and tactics
* Endless amount of expansions ensures that there will be lots more father-son gaming time
* Advanced rating: [b]7/10[/b]

RATING: 6.5
Played once.  This is a wargrame crossed with a German-style boardgame, and I'm not sure the result is ideal.  The game is reportedly trying to accurately replicate squad-level battles of WWII, and has beautifully crafted pieces and an extremely flexible board that can be used to replicate hundreds of "historically accurate" battle scenarios.  However, the mechanics of gameplay (wherein players draw cards from a deck and then play those cards to move X number of units in Y region of the board) severely hamper one's ability to command units and direct the flow of battle in a way that you'd prefer (and would be historically realistic).  Victory conditions also don't reflect the actual flow of a battle, as players can achieve victory without actually sustainably achieving their objective (e.g., there's no option for luring enemy troops into traps set at the objectives).  So, there's a lot of German-style board game in this, but to call it historically accurate would be like calling Puerto Rico a historically accurate rendering of economic development in the Caribbean.  Frustratingly, however, in their pursuit of historical accuracy some scenarios are extremely unbalanced, leading to virtually guaranteed one-sided romps, an annoying outcome for a game that takes more than an hour to setup and play.  As a final frustration, some cards are inadequately explained (e.g., air strike), leading to possible debates over exactly how much damage is caused to which units (a very bad thing in a wargame).

If I want to play a historically accurate WWII squad-level combat simulation, give me <a href="http://www.battlefront.com/products/cmbb/cmbb.html">Combat Mission: Barbarossa to Berlin</a>; if I want a German-style board game, give me Puerto Rico, Louis XIV, or any of the other great games out there.  I want to play more Memoir '44 before forming my final opinion (I especially want to play more balanced scenarios), but right now I'm not sure this hybrid has much vigor.

[Update: I think I may have been too harsh.  Must play more, but this time with more of a eurogame mentality, and less of a wargame menatlity.]

I've only played this with my son so far, but the C&C system seems to translate fairly well into this environment.  No, it's not ASL, but it was never intended to be.  Within the light wargaming sphere, it works well.

(Edit Feb 3, 2007):  I've played the game several times and finally used the cards; when I play with my son (who is 5) I typically don't use the cards. However, the game also has drawbacks (no leaders).

Overall, I like the game and will rank it similarly with Battle Cry.  The other two C&C games in the series, Battlelore and C&C:Ancients, will probably be rated higher to reflect the increased complexity in the game.

RATING: 7.7
Memoir '44 gets a lot of love, and deservedly so: it is a tremendously good WW2 game.  I love the asymmetry of the scenarios and the simplicity of the mechanisms.  The card system is simple, elegant and effective for producing a feeling of being in control, but not entirely.  I don't, however, have anyone around me who wants to play much.  

If a parent ever has the idea of buying Risk for their children, stop them and tell them to get Memoir '44 instead!

RATING: 8
The one and only game that strikes the perfect balance between board game fun, and war game strategy. Tons of minis, simple yet effective rules, and a seemingly interminable array of expansions to add to your experience. The pieces don't fit in the boxes, especially when you buy a few of the box-less expansions that you'll try to fit in there. Some storage box is definitely required here. Set up can be a little tedious after repeated plays, but there's much worse out there.

I bought this on a whim without knowing anything about the game, the system, or the designer. Never regretted it!

RATING: 10
A great 2-player game using WWII as the theme. Uses the Commands & Colours Game System, which is perfect for light\medium game players or newcomers. May not be the ideal game for heavy war gamers as the luck factor is mild to mild\high due to the use of dice and cards. Looks good on the table and plays in under an hour when experienced.

This is the most accessible and simplest of the Command & Colours System of Games. 

For both of those reasons it is also my favourite, Great expansion support only extends the shelf life of this gem but the base game offers 16 scenarios anyway so it offers great value for money.

Luck plays a reasonable part, but in truth this game is all about careful hand management (of your card based orders) and a good battle plan.

RATING: 10
One of my favorite games. Great fun and I suggest a must have. Not a heavy war game by any means. Certainly the option when your most likely partners (especially wives) aren't into fantasy. Personally, this theme my preference of all the C&C games.

Neat theme, great expansions, loads of scenarios, good duration (although can be a little long to setup).

The cards which determine the commands you can give and the dice for the battles being random, means every game is different. Even the same scenario plays totally differently. Not all scenarios are even, this is also an interesting feature. Makes this good for teaching new opponents. More user scenarios seem to appearing just recently (I just hope Battlelore doesn't steal all the focus).

Plays well with two (my wife enjoys all aspects except the setup time).

Easy to show to others who only take a few turns to grasp the workings and then they are pretty much strategising like experienced players.

RATING: 9
Excellent entry level head to head wargame for the general crowd. Probably the most famous incarnation of the Command & Colors card-based system, which restricts the actions you can take based on order cards that vary due to luck of the draw and a segmented board (thus you may be getting ready make an assault on the eastern front, but if you only get cards that give orders on the center you are forced to rethink your strategy on the fly).

Campaign books are a must, as the included scenarios are hit-and-miss, or at the very least you need to implement match-style play (play the same scenario from each side) as 90% of them are horribly balanced in favor of the allied player.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
WW II simulation boardgame. Set up terrain, troops and armor to recreate 1944 battles. Card driven game, play on left, center or right flank, like the predecessor boardgame Battle Cry and roll dice to resolve combat. A light fun game, good introductory game to more serious war games. It did make me think back on history, especially when playing an Overlord scenario.

RATING: 8.5
This is a relatively light, relatively quick dice fest, with just enough decisions to keep it interesting.  There's no high strategy, but a little hand management can help some.  On your turn, you generally want to play a card that causes the most potential damage to your enemy, and/or mitigates possible damage to you, in that priority order.  As a result, after a few plays, hands tend to play themselves, but it's still a fun affair to watch the battle play out, and occassionally the dice provide for some memorable heroics (or cowardice, as the case may be!)

RATING: 7
Better than the hexy look it has! I do like this game, despite the dice rolling. Maybe it's the historical connection. (Which if it's true makes me a nerd.) Simplicity is the key here I think. Takes a short while to set it up, and not super complex. Just place the units and terrain hexes according to the map in the rule book, and then you're off. Not a lot of counting in the battles. (For example you don't decrease in strength because you loose a soldier in your unit.) Once you know how many dice to roll, you have the result in front of you. And only one person is rolling. I recommend you to try it at least once. It plays better than you might think.

RATING: 9
Memoir '44 is an elegantly simple war game that has won over everyone I've played it with.

Although the Nazis did perform truly heinous acts in real life, the minis are just differently molded versions of the same units the Allied player is supplied with, allowing for visual ambiguity. One is just playing a game of warring factions, without being so clearly 'the bad guy'.

Its a shame that very few of the scenarios listed in the back of the instruction manual are evenly matched. I understand that by 1944 the Axis were severely outgunned, but almost none of the scenarios have the Allies at a disadvantage.

RATING: 10
Memoir '44 deserves to be considered an instant classic.  It was pure genius for Richard Borg to combine boardgaming and miniatures gaming and card gaming in his Command and Colors system.  In doing so he created a new genre of game.

The components are gorgeous.  The rules are simple, clear and beautifully presented.  There are a large number of excellent scenarios.  The game system is clean and simple, fast playing and fun.  The playability and enjoyment factor is extremely high.  The only area where there is some weakness is in the area of realism.  The game could have been given a higher degree of realism without increasing the complexity.

All in all I consider this one of the best games ever created.  It is not in the Conflict Simulation category, but as a game with a WWII theme it is unsurpassed.  I have played this game many hundreds of times, probably more times than I have played all other games put together.  I have also introduced many people to the gaming hobby by using this game, more than I have introduced with all other games put together.  And everyone I have introduced to Memoir '44 has loved it.

RATING: 8
[b]Memoir '44[/b] was reacquired* via trade (12/18/14)

[COLOR=#FF0000]A year later... thoughts and rating (8):[/COLOR]

[i]I honestly don't know what I was thinking with this one; well part of my decision was because I loved 1775 and didn't think I needed both games in my collection... wrong! (I'll blame the Jones Theory on this one)

This was a great gateway game into gaming for some of my friends and a game they still want to play. My son also really liked this game, the cool miniatures certainly helped, yet somehow I convinced myself it needed to go. 

I am now really regretting that decision, Memoir 44 and 1775 easily belong in my collection since they offer very different experiences even though they share some mechanics. Memoir plays much faster, has cool mini's and tons of scenarios to play through. This is a game I will definitely reacquire in the near future.[/i]

[COLOR=#FF0000]Initial thoughts and rating (9):[/COLOR]

[i]- Excellent intro into light war gaming, and one that my kids can play.
- Due to the dice based combat, which is very intuitive, there is enough luck in this game that the game remains very accessible. 
- This was one of the best gateway games that I introduced to friends that had formally played Risk, etc. They were instantly hooked.
- Card play: I am in the camp that enjoy the tension created by never knowing if you are going to have enough movement cards to activate one of your zones enough times to pull of your plan.
- A lot of scenarios, which all have a different terrain layout, found in the base game alone which gives this game high replay value.

This was the second designer board game added to our collection. I figured my son would love the cool army minis, and he did.

Includes the following map:

- [thing=19374][/thing][/i]

*Initially was traded away in a math trade (4/14/14)

RATING: 7
It's fun to play: as some say, it's like playing with army men except within the structure of board game rules. 

It plays really fast, is pretty intuitive, yet leaves room for several tactical decisions. And as evidenced by even the basic scenario, depending on movement and the luck of the dice, the outcomes can vary widely. 

I got this for my step-son for Christmas 2006, and unfortunately he didn't show much interest in it, so I ended up playing it. The scenarios can be played pretty quickly, and one can add in complexity as one goes through the scenario booklet. In all, it's a clever game, one of those I wish I'd thought of. It's a good design, with typically outstanding Days of Wonder production, and scenarios that play out in a short amount of time, which is appropriate given the relative simplicity of the design. At the same time, Richard Borg absolutely nailed the design concept of making a game with some depth as simple as possible, with the absolute minimum of rules, and yet touching all the basic bases for simulating WW2 combat. 

Combat is bloody, and the game really shines head-to-head. I give the game an extra star for proving itself as a design over such a long period of time--12 years as of 2016.

RATING: 9
100+ plays. This is my preferred game using this system - it's an attractive theme, the rules are not as complex as Battlelore, the tanks provide more dynamism than Battle Cry. That dynamism breaks down the conservative defensive approach typically taken by troops, making the game more fun. No doubt it's heavily luck-laden, from the dice to the cards, but you can play smart and dumb, and smart will win using combinations and weight of numbers, waiting until the time is right to strike hard. All the different available scenarios provide all the variety of tactical situations you should need, especially if you start adding in variants.

RATING: 10
An excellent game, not only to introduce new and inexperienced players to war gaming, but because of its almost endless replay value, a great game for experienced gamers.
The only 'negative' is identified by statistical nerd bean counter, rules lawyer types! That it is 'not very realistic', I don't think we need to use much imagination to imagine what the 'ultimate' in realism would be.
Thankfully, those types are very much in their own 'minority' leaving, for the enjoyment of the 'majority', this wonderful and fun game.
The other negative is also quoted by the above group, that of the luck element regarding the card draw mechanism, my advice to them is to 'carefully' read any actual account of an encounter and the obviousness of the involvement of opportune fortune will shout out to them!
If I could give a higher than 10, then I certainly would!
Oh! my qualifications for making this statement: 45+ years as a wargamer, model builder and boardgamer, i.e. 'quite qualified'.
In closing: there are two basic categories of 'games', 1, a game, or 2, a 'simulation', sometimes, but rarely does one also satisfy the other, i.e. true simulations rarely make fun or good games (other than to the previously identified group)!

In seguito ho scoperto - e apprezzato - il motivo per cui le carte azione sono pescate a caso e fanno sì che il grosso dell'esercito possa rimanere bloccato per tutta la partita: Borg ha voluto rendere nel gioco l'assoluta difficoltà nelle comunicazioni nelle battaglie della seconda guerra mondiale. Spiegazione convincente! I pregi sono comunque superiori al difetto. da rigiocare (e le partite durano talmente poco che si concede sempre una rivincita).

RATING: 6
A pleasant experience but if I want to play a 2 player wargame I prefer something a little meatier. There's something about the game I'm not sure about.

It's not the cards as combat commander and manoeuvre prove the fun of tactical CDGs.

It's not the plastic soldiers as warfighter and tide of iron give me a great nostalgia buzz during games.

Perhaps I started my wargaming at a slightly higher level- I dived head first into Lnls nations at war series as one of my first tactical wargames and bought memoir about 3 years later due to a few others recommendations.

Or perhaps it's that for me this style of card play doesn't quite match up to my take on WW2 tactical gaming. Fantasy, ancients, medieval even WW1 seem fine with 'wing' activations but for me WW2 is a bit of a stretch but clearly I'm in the minority when it comes to this game.

If I want a fun/fast(ish) 2 player Ww2 experience I think for me a similar level would be spearpoint 1943 with the terrain board Expansion and also the bonus of a faster setup time.

RATING: 6
an OK game. Not bad, not great, just ok. It's entertaining and I don't think it's as bad as people say and it definitely isn't as good as people say either. After playing real war-games I can't take this one too seriously. It's very luck driven. Now I don't mind luck, it's just that this one is a little excessive for what it is and brings the game down a bit. Some kind of luck mitigation would have been nice. I do understand why the design is the way it is though.

I do praise the game on the merits that anyone in your family can play this. It's a great game to play with kids and casual gamers. I'd say it's a good gate-way game potentially to war games. A decent family game.

My rating is based on all the expansions. Some scenarios are terrible and ruin the game. Play the best and most interesting scenarios when introducing the game, otherwise it will fall flatter than a pancake.

edit: people have been telling me that playing the overlord expansion is the way to play this game. I will have to give that a try and see if my opinion changes.

edit: After looking into the overlord version of the game I'm inclined to agree with what others say. It seems to be the way to play. More fun and more luck mitigation and control.

Also I've come to realize that while this game has a wargame theme it's not really a war game. It's a tactical conflict hand management game. You must manage your hand and resources as best as possible given the situation. Looking at this game from a wargame perspective is only going to make you disappointed.

I'm considering increasing this game to an 8 rating...time will tell.

RATING: 8
An exellent game. The war theme works well even though it doesn't reflect into the game very much.

I play other games to have more realistic experience of the war and have some heavier strategies. This one though needs no any more realism. 

The main point is that this game is fun to play! Player gets to plan some strategies, and even though they may not be actual strategies straight from WWII, I don't care. Card-drawing affects your choices heavily and do not let me even begin with the dice.

Really a great game, not a simulation, game!

RATING: 5
Played this a lot before signing up for an account, mostly with my dad. He eventually sold his copy, plus all the expansions. Truthfully, I don't miss the game. 

The base set seemed streamlined and efficient, but that changed quickly. When all the expansions started piling up, my eyes began to glaze over. Enough with "more soldiers" thing, we've got a box of them already! The new sets added a few more rules to look up, a few more figures to organize, and some more stuff taking up space under the bed. 

While the card directed action still seems innovative, the game no longer provides the level of engagement I'm looking for (I was never too crazy about the WW2 theme, anyway). It's still a great game, but after sampling other games, I can't think of a reason to return to World War two. Maybe my interest in games evolved to the point where I outgrew Memoir '44. I don't know. It's like the  relationship we had with our first boyfriend. He was okay ...for the time. We may still think fondly of him, and remember the great times we had, but eventually we moved on. Is that such a bad thing?

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
M'44 is now obsolete for me, it's only saving grace is its subject matter.

This is the classic C&C implementation again, only with WWII figures, components, considerations, and combat.  This means it is mostly a duck'n'cover routine, with occasional running, shooting, so on and so forth.  I think of the three games that I own that utilize this type of system (this, BattleLore, C&C:A) I must say I like this the least.  I find that this game does, truly, rely heavily on the card draw.  There are no mechanisms in place to allow you to try and make best of what you have.  Having played it many times with the same friend, we often quote "..having hot dice rolls is important, but without the right cards you don't have a chance."  There it is.  In this game there is no battle-back, just defense.  This makes only the scenarios where, historically, there is no clear winner the most interesting of the bunch.  Anything else -- it's just not as fun.  If you are in it for the minis (AKA, you have a young child but want to have some fun) I'd definately recommend BattleLore over this.  If you are looking for a better implementation of the same system, I'd reach for Command and Colors: Ancients.

When do I play this?:
If I had a 8 year old son, I'd be playing it all of the time.  Instead, I have a mid-20s girlfriend who isn't so gusto into the whole thing, but she humors me from time to time. All and all, this is a fun game, but because it's only for two players (best played, anyways) it doesn't get as much table time as I would like.

RATING: 8
hmmm...I don't want to give this game a 10 but I feel I have to.  I keep playing it.  With more than 200 games under my belt and this still seems to get played weekly.  The more I play it the more I like it.  So it started out at an 8, crept up to a 9, and finally a 10.

Luck? There is no more luck to this game than Settlers of Catan.  Planning is critical.  You must always play the current card with the card 2 turns down the road in mind.  If you do this, you will win more than your fair share.

The replayability is almost endless.  I hope to see more expansions from Days of Wonder.

Lowered to a 7 - approaching burnout.  

Back up to an 8, hope they come out with more campaigns.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Memoir '44 might as well be the best gateway game for wargaming out there. Command cards (unit activation), terrain, scenarios, line of sight etc. many elements of classic wargaming are in there. And yet, the game is just as simple as most Days of Wonder games, if not simpler and it is still tremendous fun. Being a 2-player game, the basic gameplay is very much like an extended (in variety, not in complexity of course) version of chess, take turns in moving your units, fire away and hope for the best. I think the game can appeal to a wide range of gamers (excluding the unnecessarily serious) because of the luck element. To me, it makes the game more dynamic and fun, will I be going to draw the right cards, roll the symbols I need etc. All this and the fact that there are myriads of expansions out there make this an absolute winner.

EDIT: Having played this a few times in a row recently, I still love but sometimes long for something similar of slightly higher complexity (i.e C&C Ancients or Combat Commander) - Maybe I just need an expansion ?

RATING: 7
this game has really fun cool looking bits and a cool variable map/scenario system. i really wanted to like this game more than i did. i just found the combat system to be overly simplistic for my tastes. i also got annoyed by the order cards. sometimes bad draws mean you can go a whole turn or two without having anything effective to do on your turn. i will say that i find the claim that the scenarios are unbalanced to be overstated. there are usually different win conditions for both sides. despite being cursed by the dice gods, i have won as the germans in scenarios where they were at a disadvantage. i can see why people like this, and i wouldn't mind playing on occasion, but ultimately this game is not for me. (i've actually traded away two different copies of this game)

update: after playing C&C Ancients, I've come to appreciate the simple and straight-forward game play that this incarnation of the C&C systems offers.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
28-06-2015. Rated after 4 (recent) plays. Memoir '44 is a simpler version of Battlelore Second Edition. You basically each turn play a card that allows you to play certain units. 

You move, attack. Both work very easily and hits are calculated based on the units you are attacking. You can damage units (remove figures from the hex), have them retreat etc.

You aim to get objectives, like occupying villages etc. The game is nice, fun, good. But I rather play with a LITTLE more complexity like Battlelore 2 offers.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 8.75
A great game for 2 players. Each game is a recreation of a battle from the WWII European theater between the Allied forces and the Axis powers. 

This is a light wargame where your strategy and tactics ultimately come down to a dice roll. While bad for an unlucky player, the dice keep the game moving along nicely. As much as a board game will allow, you will get a good feel for what it was like to be a part of these historic battles as you command infantry, tank and artillery units around the battlefield. 

The expansions are awesome, exciting and highly recommended. They feature additional theaters of war such as the Pacific, North Africa and the Eastern front.

RATING: 10
Awesome - best "wargame" I've ever played, but I really love WWII. I keep trying more advanced wargames (Combat Commander, Tide of Iron), but none provide the fun factor of Memoir. I find that in Memoir, the luck of the dice rolling is less a factor than in some of the other more advanced games like Combat Commander.  You can get screwed with the cards in Memoir just like in Combat Commander, but usually you only get screwed because your opponent was successful in destroying most of the units in one section and you are stuck with useless cards, whereas in CC you can often just have a hand of useless cards.  Not sure exactly why, but I don't like Commands and Colors at all - partly because I don't like blocks.  I enjoy Battle Cry, which is the closest match to Memoir, but would always prefer to play Memoir.

RATING: 8
Gift from [b]Secret Santa 2011![/b]

I don't get to play this game often as my wife doesn't enjoy shooting at me with tanks. But I really enjoy this game when I get around the couple people I've been able to play it with.

It's easy, it's fun, it's thematic enough even though it's quite abstract, and there is more depth & decision making available than may appear at first glance. Sure, you can just throw down cards without much thought and do okay sometimes.  But maneauver and well timed attacks will win out against lucky card draws, lucky die rolls, and poor tactics most times.

Memoir is a uncomplicated to teach and to grasp and fun to play. I wish I had the opportunnity to play it more. Highly recommended!

RATING: 9
I'm not generally a fan of WW2-themed games. There's something about that theme which feels old and drab to me, probably thanks to how much time I was forced to spend hearing about it at school. 

Memoir '44 is neither of those things. 

It's one of the best games I've played, impeded only by being designed for two players only. It has a nice balance of tactics and strategy, a fair dollop of chance but not too much, and it plays in less than an hour. I'd say most games of Memoir I've played have lasted 30-40 minutes. 

Well worth anyone's time, regardless of whether the theme is appealing.

RATING: 8
It's just fun to play. I prefer games over simulations, and while I wouldn't want too many games this streamlined, what it lacks in minute detail it makes up for with pure gaming fun. Playing smart and using the cards effectively will outweigh the luck of the dice in almost all cases - the dice play an important role in ASL too. I appreciate a WW2 game that keeps it simple and puts the emphasis on fun. I embrace the game for what it is. Because I can play it with kids and adults, because it plays quickly, because the rules are easy, because it's just fun, because of the re-playability of the game with all the possible scenarios, because of all these things it has risen in the ranking for me. With the right crowd, and that's a crowd that can embrace the luck of the dice, this is an excellent little ride.

Eastern Front really opens the game up and is my number one expansion. There's some good scenarios and extra units / rules changes that don't overly complicate Memoir 44. I wouldn't own the base game without it. With it you can begin to look at some of the other expansions.

To top it off my second expansion would be the Air Pack. The planes themselves aren't fantastic, but they do add another dimension. The cleaned up scenario book is equally as attractive as the planes. That said, I've always found weakened units running away out of harms way in Memoir 44 to be a bit of a cop out. Except when they're mine of course. The planes in the Air Pack are good for mopping up and picking on tanks hiding in woods or towns. The feature of having to move planes every turn they're on simulates loitering time and fuel reserves nicely. It also means you'll be more likely to wait until you really need them for picking of those weakened units and you've got the run of cards that will guarantee the planes will be in the air for a few turns. End placement between two sectors and weighing this up between terrain modifiers and adjacent ground troops is a positive move towards making the Air Pack addition an intelligent add-on.

Finally, for a third expansion I'd either start to look at the battle maps - very reasonably priced and the Sword of Stalingrad (with close combat cards) and Tigers in the Snow (with Tiger tanks), are the best of the bunch. If you want a very different Memoir 44 experience with lots of positioning (and longer play time), then the long double sided Breakthrough map really changes the way the game is played as units must be positioned more, often before the fighting gets serious.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 6
I find the cards make the game seem quite artificial. There is nothing more frustrating than not being able to attack with the right guys because you do not have the right cards. While meant to be a part of the design and insure that hand management is part of the game, it makes for unappealing strategy.

Also, I don't like how damaged units still shoot at full power, combined with the objective being to take out a set number of units. My handful of games have often come down to sniping out the final damaged unit.

Finally, I wish they presented more balanced scenarios. Almost every time I've played (which is only a handful), I switched places after playing and the same side won.
