=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
Today’s review will be on the board game Memoir ’44.
As the title implies, this is a World War II strategy board game for two players. It was released in 2004 by Days of Wonder, a Board Game company based in the U.S. and France. The game was developed by a guy named Richard Borg using his Command and Colors system which Borg has used in a few dozen other games and expansions. 
Gameplay under the command and colors system is pretty easy to pick up. The board is divided into three flanks. Each player has a certain number of cards which allow him or her to use actions to move and shoot with units in the various flanks. Some cards only let you move units in one flank, while others let you move a few in all flanks. There are also a few special ability cards thrown in for good measure. Dice are used to resolve combat encounters. The score is tracked by how many medals each player has. Medals are earned by capturing and holding points on the map or wiping out enemy units.
Now that you understand how the game works, let’s see how it stacks up in the review.

While I will give the game a numerical score, what’s really important is the content of the review. A type of gameplay that I like may just rub you the wrong way, making my score irrelevant. So rather than focusing on the number I give it, take a moment and decide if the ups and downs of the game fit what you want to get out of a game. I review games based on three main criteria...presentation, mechanics and gameplay, and value. Each criterion has sub points that I’ll discuss as we go. So let’s start off with presentation.
The first part of presentation is artwork and style.
The artists decided to take a realistic approach to the visual look of this game. The units are colored in muted greens and grays and the battle surface is painted in similarly realistic fashion. The overall effect is nice, but it’s not without its drawbacks. Because of the bird’s eye view approach, it can be tough to tell what some of the terrain pieces are supposed to represent. Also, the colors chosen for the symbols on the dice kind of clash with the rest of the game. The neon oranges and purples, while admittedly neat looking, just don’t fit with the realistic approach the rest of the game took.
The cards are a pretty big component of this game, and fortunately they are printed in a clear and easy to read format. You can tell exactly what flank the card activates and how many units you can use by just glancing at them.

So out of a possible score of 10, I give the artwork and style a nine point oh. The overall style and effect works, but there are a few bizarre outliers like the dice and terrain that are a bit of a detractor.
The second part of presentation is the quality of the pieces. It’s here that Memoir ’44 really shines. When I opened the box I was blown away by the durability of everything from the board to the box itself. The board is thick and well made. It’s double sided and folds into a nice compact square for storage. The plastic used in manufacturing the units is clearly high quality and the individual units just feel good to the touch. They’re not made of the cheap slippery plastic that some of these game companies use. I have had no problem with the components of the game, so I will go ahead and give the quality of the pieces a 10 out of 10.

The third and final component to presentation is the rulebook. It may sound strange, but I firmly believe that a rulebook needs to be clear for the game to work. If you have to go online to figure out how to play the game because the company included 8 pages of incomprehensible gobbledygook, the game certainly suffers. The rulebook for Memoir fares pretty well. Richard Borg, the designer, is American so the rules have the advantage of having been written in English in the first place and not translated from another language. The rules are presented straight forward with plenty of pictures to accompany the text. The game also comes with some nifty cheat-sheet cards. Although the rules are pretty thorough, there are a few rare anomalies that pop up during the game that aren’t covered in the rules. In addition, I would have liked to see a little more explanation of some of the ‘special ability’ cards. I also take umbridge with the wording of some of the scenarios, which are included in the back of the rulebook. Each and every scenario in every version of the game, every expansion of the game, even on the custom content ends with the same boring sentence. It’s a minor thing, to be sure, but you do get sick of reading the cheesy line every time you play a game. Despite these issues, though, the rulebook earns a 9.5.
These three components, art and style, quality of pieces, and rulebook give us a combined presentation score of 9.5 out of 10.

Now on to the meat of the game…the mechanics and gameplay. Memoir ’44 is an easy game to pick up and play. The card-based nature of the command and colors system is fairly self-explanatory…pick a card, move the units, roll of the dice for combat, draw a new card. Its simplicity means that it is really easy to teach new players. By the end of one game, they not only get the rules…they’re hooked!

The games themselves are fairly short. In my experience the average battle takes no more than 40 minutes. I’ve played through the landing at Omaha beach in less than half an hour! I personally like the brevity of the games and I know a lot of people don’t like to play a war game that lasts 6 hours. On the other hand, I know there are people who like that sort of drawn out experience. Just know what you’re getting into when you play this game. Because the battles are so short, you can easily make the game experience longer by playing through a few scenarios in one sitting.

The brevity of the battles, though, has some noteworthy drawbacks. Indeed, the battles sometimes feel just too short and they almost always feel like they come down to the last few turns. Sure, this makes for some exciting battles, but this almost feels too luck based. When playing I’ve always felt I have just barely enough control over making meaningful decisions, but since there is no clear victor until the last turn or two, it really does sometimes feel like all my decisions up until the final few moves are wasted.

The command and colors system itself can be a source of strife for some players. The system forces you to go from flank to flank according to what the cards you draw dictate. This means that sometimes you will be getting butchered on your left flank but just don’t have the cards to do anything about it, or on the other hand you may have finally gained the upper hand in the center but are unable to follow up, again because of the cards. While this does in some ways model the confusion of the real battlefield, it can be frustrating watching your units dying off in one flank while the cards force you to focus on another. 

The game does a good job of balancing out these frustrating moments and honestly, they don’t really happen too often. I’m just getting nitpicky with the review. In general, the battles are exciting and tense and like I said earlier I usually feel like I have enough control to make my decisions meaningful. Despite the drawbacks, the gameplay holds up to repeat playing. I’m certainly always up for a quick game. So I give the mechanics and gameplay of Memoir ’44 a score of 9 out of 10.

The final criterion I judge a game by is the value. This score is made up of price and replayability.
I know price is very subjective, so I look at the cost versus what you get in the box. In terms of price, this game does fairly well. I picked this up for about 50 at The Last Square in Madison, Wisconsin and I always recommend you buy games from your local mom and pop game store rather than online. For that price, you get a sturdy set of pieces, a durable game board, a fairly well developed mechanic, and over a dozen scenarios. I give the price 9.5 out of 10.

The other component of value is replayability, and Memoir ’44 is chock full of it! As I just said, the basic game comes with over a dozen scenarios based around the Normandy invasions and aftermath, and the various expansion packs have added another 50 or 60 scenarios based on the various theaters of World War II. There’s even an aviation expansion that adds air power, though I haven’t played it so I can’t really comment of its quality. Days of Wonder has also released a scenario maker through their website and players from around the world have submitted their own scenarios. The website has a good rating system that lets you sift through the garbage to find the golden user-submitted scenarios. My own dad made a scenario for BattleCry, the Civil War game also based on the Command and Colors system. The terrain pieces make it easy for you to set up the map however you want. And the short nature of the battles always leave you wanting to play just one more round. I give Memoir ’44 a replayability score of 10.

This gives us a total value score of 9.8.

So sending all of these scores through the tabubolator gives Memoir ’44 a combined overall score of 9.5. Sure, it has its faults. Some of the game art strays from the realistic theme, sometimes the games just feel too short, and the card-based nature of the game means that you are sometimes pigeon-holed into focusing on one flank when the battle is really happening in another. But the game balances these frustrations with some truly exhilarating moments into a well-polished, two-player game based on World War II. If you like war games or strategy games, and just have one friend like I do, it’s worth giving this one a spin.

RATING: 9
[17 plays] Days Of Wonder with Richard Borg have incorporated many of the best house rules developed for his excellent Avalon Hill "Battle Cry", added some new ideas and mechanics, and given it a WW2 theme and killer components.

If there are limitations on your game collection, I don't think you need to own both M'44 and Battle Cry. Choose the game in which you have the strongest historical interest.

I believe the command and control card system with a 3 section battlefield is a better fit historically with its predecessor Battle Cry than it is here for the WW2 theme of Memoir '44, but it is a great game regardless.

I rate Battle Cry just a tad higher for its originality, out of love for all the great gaming we got out of it originally (and still do), and for my fondness for Civil War history.

Most recent play 7-13-12 with Garrett, Michael, Corey, and Donovan.

Dice seem to have a bad reputation in modern board gaming, but memoir 44 does the dice rolling pretty well.

RATING: 10
This game is awesome. The rules are incredibly simple, but its easy and fun to play. Despite my wife kicking my ass the first few plays I still enjoyed this.
The only possible criticism of this game is that the scenarios will eventually feel repetative after you've played it a lot. But thats the only downside to an otherwise great game.
When I first rated this game I said that eventually the scenarios would begin to feel too similar, even though there are 16 of them in the initial rules.
I should have read the rulebook properly for on the back there is an ID number. Put this into the Memoir44 website and you have access to a whole ton of scenarios, and even a scenario generator (although you pay a small fee for that part). Then of course there are expansion packs. All in all I can't see myself ever getting bored of this one.
This game rocks so hard it should have its own MTV channel.

RATING: 3
With all the buzz around this game I had high hopes for this one, but I have to say I am truly disappointed. The game have nice components, but there are no hard decisions at all in the game. You always know what the best move is but you might not be able to execute it because you have the wrong card in your hand. Other card driven games have alternate functions of the cards which help to prevent a player from getting "dead" cards in his hand and always be able to make some sort of reasonable move. Not so here. Do not believe the hype. Stay away from this!

RATING: 7
I wanted to like Memoir '44, as I am interested in the setting.  Days of Wonder has produced a very high quality boardgame, the bits and board and cards were all well made, and the rules were streamlined yet effective.

However, staying with realism has made most battles obviously one-sided; I respect realism and honestly am glad that it was used, but one side enters the game with a defeatist attitude.  The rulebook even states to play scenarios twice, so that the other player can be the loser.  I would have been a lot happier if there was even the slightest bit more balance to the game.  It's pretty depressing to know you'll most likely lose from the get-go.

Edit: The more board games I play, the more this seems like just a toy.  Not a good thing.

Edit edit: Okay, I've played it a bit more and it is pretty fun, and approachable for people new to board games.  Maybe not as bad as I thought.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 5
For adolescent boys, easily a 9+. It's quick and easy, and looks nice. The modular board and flexible system encourage experimentation and creativity. I would have loved this when I was 12.

For games between adults, though, Memoir is mediocre at best. It's too simple to be a good simulation and too random to be a good strategy game. The pieces are cool, but a pain to setup, move around, and keep track of. Get something from the Conflict of Heroes line if you want a fun, reasonably light tactical wargame.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
Fantastic game! Owned by my brother-in-law. The day he bought it we played through the first 6 scenarios, back to back. Next time we played we played another 3.

All scenarios are extremely asymmetric, something I usually like in a boardgame. Many of them also feel quite unbalanced, which is of course not very nice in most games. However, in Memoir '44 it's completely fine that scenarios are unbalanced. It's very much in line with the historical setting, and which side is favoured changes between scenarios.

We've been playing with me as the Allies and my brother-in-law as the Axis and after the first 9 scenarios I'm in the lead with 5 victories against 4. While some scenarios seem almost impossible to win for one side (I'm looking at you Omaha Beach), when played as a campaign, fortune really ebbs and flows in a great way. (I think there is a rulebook for real campaign play, but here I'm just talking about playing the same side through all the scenarios, in order.)

If you just want to sit down to play a single game against someone, you might want to gauge the scenarios a little, and either pick one that seems fairly balanced, or make sure the less experienced player gets the easier side.

RATING: 8.5
I had a lot of plays of "Battle Cry" and "BattleLore" under my belt before I played "Memoir '44" for the first time.  It is definitely a step up from "Battle Cry", and when comparing it to "BattleLore" I would say that the emphasis in "Memoir '44" seems to be on the various terrain and obstacles, whereas the emphasis in "BattleLore" is more on the individual units and weapons, which creates a fairly different playing experience between both those games.  A few things that "Memoir '44" has going for it are that fact that it is a little simpler to play than "BattleLore", it's setup time is not nearly as painfully long, and it seems to play a little quicker.  This means that it's easier to play a game, swap sides, and replay the same scenario.  And who doesn't love plastic tanks!  Game design: 4.5/5  Personal enjoyment: 4/5  Total: 8.5/10

RATING: 8
Okay...this game is one that falls between categories for me.  "Hardcore" wargamers will not claim it as a wargame and a lot Ameritrashers wouldn't touch it because it is about history and war. 

I spent 20+ years as a historical miniature wargamer and board gamer.  This game allows me to get a quick wargame on the table that doesn't require me to spend hours painting, setting up terrain etc.  This was the first adult board game that my son and I played.  We have a blast playing it and lots of great memories.  

I rate it an 8 because it is a good gateway game for either someone who likes history, pre-teen kid, or anyone looking for a better version of risk.  

I'm sure it will see less time on the table as my son gets older and his tastes change, but for now, I will play it anytime he wants to build some memories for us.

Laura's Rank (4/15) – 3.0 out of 5. Pros: I think this is a good game overall. I like the scenarios and how it changes the game up every time. Cons: I have to be in the right mood to want to play it. The theme doesn't really grab me as fun, compared to many of our other games.

Ryan's Rank (4/15) – 4.0 out of 5. I really, really like this game. I love WWII as a theme, and while this is a bit heavier game than a lot of stuff we have played thus far, it all makes good sense and the rules are pretty clear. I don't like how vague some of the command cards are, so we end up using the online FAQ a fair amount (which is a great resource). Who doesn't love playing with army men?! The only thing keeping me from a 4.5 is the time it takes to set up and properly play both sides of a scenario. That (and Laura's lower ranking) means it doesn't come to the table as often as I would probably like.

RATING: 7
At first I resisted the luck factor and how much it disrupted strategies. It can be frustrating when you have no cards to repel a fierce attack in a particular sector and no advantage to gain attacking in the other sectors.

But after enough plays it balances out. You get lucky, you get unluck, but most of the time, you're faced with interesting decisions because the optimal on-board is not possible with the cards you hold. This makes for a fast, slick, surprisingly deep strategy experience.

The game is a fantastic piece of design, if nothing else, and for me at least is less about who wins the battle (some of which are somewhat one-sided for historical reasons), and more about being entertained by the game's rhythm. Strangely addictive, and highly recommended.

RATING: 8
The mechanics make this game for me. I love how the available orders are randomised and only allow you to move a few men at a time on only a few sections of the board. Furthermore I love how the battles are so easily resolved with the simply roll of a die which are so ingeniously printed with the unit symbols on them.

Most of all though I love the modular maps and the variety of missions. It is worth noting the superb production quality also the boards are thick as anything (nowhere near as thick as the Tide of Iron boards though) and the units are just the right size so you can easily tell them apart and manoeuvre them.

RATING: 8
I have a funny history with Memoir 44. When Battlelore was all the rage, I borrowed M44 from a friend to try it out with my wife to see if we'd like the game mechanics enough to buy Battlelore. We enjoyed M44, and eventually bought Battlelore. After playing Battlelore a couple of times, I began to find myself thinking more about M44. Battlelore just feels like a re-hashed version of M44, with many card mechanics being re-arranged to appear in Lore cards instead of regular Command Cards. M44 just felt more.. fun. I mean, you have scenarios where you air-drop your infantry from 3 feet off the board and start them off where they land. How cool is that!?

Now I've bought myself a copy of M44 and much prefer it to Battlelore.

3 Dec 07: 7.5 --> 8.0. Just can't get enough of it. Yeah, sometimes the card draws are crap, but the sheer fun of moving men around and shooting stuff is simply addictive.

RATING: 9
When I got this game, as a veteran wargamer, I really expected to be disappointed.  But the opposite turned out to be true.  Okay, it does not have the detail of many war games but that can be a major advantage.  My friends don't want to sit down to a 4+ hour battle where they struggle with the rules continuously.  Memoir 44 scenarios can be played over a lunch hour, often twice, once as Axis and once as Allies. The large number of accessible scenarios and campaigns without a hefty investment in miniatures is also a positive.  I would recommend this game to anyone.  Checkout Tom Vasel's video review if you are still skeptical.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 9.5
A simple game, barely a wargame due to how light it is and how lacking it is in flavour induced rules, but so streamlined. The combat system feels like a skirmish is happening. Not necessarily in the sense that everything is happening at once like in Warhammer, but more encapsulates how flanks operate, suppressing fire, and looking for an enemies' weak spot. Certain units may move and fight more than others, based on terrain, or suppressing fire, stamina, morale or choke points. But none of this needs pages of rules to simulate; rather, the gameplay itself brings to life these variables, with card play and tough player decisions. Memoir 44 might seem like a mere gateway war game, but there is so much depth there.

RATING: 10
I thought to myself one time, "How will I know when I find a ten rating? Maybe one of my nines is a ten in disguise." The answer is: you just know. Memoir '44 was immediately a ten; the gameplay is excellent and tense, the history behind the scenarios are an essential aspect of the rulebook, and learning the game took no time at all. It has the right balance of luck and strategy, enough cards to keep me happy and dice to keep my husband satisfied. The detail involved in the making of this game is simply astounding--even the armor design is accurate to the time period and side. If there were any complaint, it would be that set-up and take-down can go on a little long. Since we tend to play at least two games--one on each side of a scenario--that still doesn't seem too bad for us. I could go on about Memoir '44, but I think it's hard to understand the greatness of the game if you haven't played, which may be why it took me a while to finally buy it. I'm glad I did!

RATING: 9
So far I'm loving everything about this game.  Set up can take a while, but I actually enjoy it.  Its like playing with army men.

Most of my games have been solo.  I've tried a few different approaches; playing both sides, playing one side and drawing a random card for the other.  Not sure which I like better and if there are more optimal choices out there.  

I've heard criticisms about the cards forcing too much luck.  I disagree.  #1 I do think it imitates the chaos of battle.  And #2, I don't think its too limiting.  Sure you may not get the exact draw you were hoping for, but it forces you to think on your feet and be flexible.  There are enough generic battle cards to even it out.  

Looking forward to getting the Eastern front, winter/desert map, and terrain pack next.

RATING: 8
Essentially Battle Cry set in WW2, Memior '44 corrects some of the (few) flaws in the original C&C games and provides a very polished fast paced WW2 game. The expansions have been great as well, adding tons of depth and replayability. For some reason the Command and Colors system feels a bit more abstract in Memior '44 than in the other games in the C&C series (probably because of its setting), so I prefer BattleLore and Command and Colors: Ancients, but its hard to beat Memior '44 if you are looking for a fun light weight WW2 game. The Overlord rules are still my favorite way to play the game, and the best multi-player implementation of the C&C series so far. 

The rating is based on playing in Overlord mode. Without Overlord, this drops to a 7 because of the increased luck in Memior due to the lack of "Battle Back" rules.

I picked this up back in 2008 and have played it a lot over the years. Thought it's a 2-player game, you can easily play with more people. The game is fairly simple, but that's what makes it so good. There are loads of extra scenarios on the web, and you can even make your own. This means that the game is different every time you play it. 

The only problem I have with this game is that the sides can be a bit unbalanced. This can be fixed by playing a scenario twice, once as each side, and comparing victory points in the end. Though that means the game takes longer.

RATING: 10
I used to think I just couldn't get into a wargame. (I know that this technically isn't a wargame, according to the pro wargamers, but you know what I mean.)

I heard and read so much good feedback about Memoir '44 that I finally gave it a shot when a coworker gave me his copy.

I have been pleasantly surprised. I've been loving this game for two primary reasons:

1. I love tactical games, which this is.
2. It's much easier than Squad Leader - which is the other wargame I've played.

On top of that, other people have enjoyed playing with me, my wife included.

There are also plenty of expansions and a great website and online community.

EDIT (5/18/2011): I just updated my rating from 9.5 to 10 because I realized that I want to play it just as often as, or more often than, my other 10-rated game - Dominion.

EDIT (4/14/2015): This game continues to be my favorite still years later, even though I'm usually not in the mood for gaming.

RATING: 8
A lot of people have complained that the cards ruin the strategy by bringing too much luck into the game.  I think the opposite, in that the cards provide a "handicap" that changes every time and make each game fresh.  If you want a 100% strategy and no luck game then stay away, you will be frustrated.  But if you want to test your strategy against "all comers", including sudden shifts of gameplay, Memoir 44 can be an intensely exciting game.  The board tokens and hex pieces are also awesome!

RATING: 7
Solid 'gateway game' toward more serious historical miniature wargaming.

Excellent 'dueling' game, as tension between victory conditions keeps things interesting for the entire playthrough.  Do consider swapping sides and seeing who wins by the largest margin, as missions are often imbalanced - as historically appropriate.

Dice and card mechanics add a moderate luck factor that is both a) thematically appropriate and b) a powerful equalizer of player skill.  However, games do not tend to feel won or lost 'by luck of the draw', but by personal strategy and maneuver.

RATING: 10
Playing the game with the "Overlord" rules - with eight players, probably ranks an "11".Is this popularity deserved? The answer is that Memoir '44 is the pinnacle - the absolute best of light modern war games. With the tried-and-true system Borg invented in Battle Cry perfected - Memoir '44 plays smoothly, quickly, and provides a pile of fun! The game can be taught in less than 10 minutes, but has definite strategies, but with enough luck to make each game varied.  I usually can say something negative about most games, but Memoir is a game without error - a masterpiece of fun and excellence.  The expansions only add to the fun - with the Air Pack probably being the best.

RATING: 8
This is such a guilty pleasure. It's so quick and easy to play, though setup can take a little while. If both players are working together to set it up, it's not too bad at all. It tickles the chuck lots of dice, have a few laughs, beer and pretzels itch.

I play with the variant where you have a pool of additional command cards that either player has access to. Been testing out between 3 to 5 cards and it's been really good. I also play the variant if there are temporary medals on the board, the player who benefits from the additional temporary medals must hold all the objectives in order to win. It doesn't matter if they've already killed enough squads to gain the medals required to win the objective. This might imbalance some of the missions, but I've found it a lot more fun.

Expansions:
Eastern Front
Pacific Theater
Mediterranean Theater
Terrain Pack
Winter Wars
Operation Overlord
Breakthrough
Air Pack
Campaign Book Vol 1
Campaign Book Vol 2
Winter/Desert Board
Sword of Stalingrad

RATING: 7
Endlessly re-playable ultralight wargame that does a great job of simulating the fog of war and the vagaries of the chain of command. 

+ Practically no teaching time required
+ Plays in 30-45 minutes
+ It's FUN



- Strangely ambiguous rules regarding beach and ocean movement. Still haven't entirely figured it out.

- Tanks make little sense. You can really tell that they're cavalry units from other C&C games with slightly different abilities. They're fragile, ineffective when attacking buildings and bunkers (whatever happened to concussive blasts?), and often seem like more of a liability than an asset. Yes, they're powerful when used effectively, but the way you have to use them seems counterintuitive and just doesn't say "tank" to me. Also, artillery units are harder to hit than tanks... 


Update: I have degraded my rating slightly after my exposure to C&C Ancients and Napoleonics, which retain the low entry barrier but have far more depth of play.

RATING: 8
After three matches, the game seems to be a little bit too light for my liking. I will happily play it, though. It's a fast and very light wargame and there not that many competitors in that genre. The cards and the dice usually mean, that you can't give orders to those units, that you would like, so luck is a big factor. Bigger than skills, I think.

Add about 20 match-up games and more distance to war games (in timely sense) and the game feels rather good. Of course the dice and the cards bring random elements in to the game, but they even each other quite well - and the other player has the same problems. Also the game is quick, you don't need to think about every cunning strategy, because you are not able to perform them. You need to manage with the cards you have.

The theme is great (for me, might not be that hot for others) and the components are good looking. Only minus thing is the color palette, at least in my kitchen light the grey and green are sometimes hard to distinguish... I have now played every scenario on both sides and I'm looking for the expansion to give more content and life time to the game.

I have finished the game second time on both sides and started going through the Eastern Front.

I updated the rating from 7 to 8 (01-DEC-2013), because, well, I like to play this game. I wouldn't necessarily want to teach the game to anyone new, but if the rules are known, then this is a nice game to play.

I have now played Eastern Front and Pacific Theater on both sides, still like the game. Next up Terrain Pack or Sword of Stalingrad scenarios. Using the expansions adds rules AND setup time, lots of more hexes to select from, special rules and so on... Best to play one scenario both sides at one go to decrease setup time.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 7
The second game in the Command and Colors system, this one set in WWII. Every C&C release shows constant evolution and Memoir '44 is a big improvement over the system first presented in Battlecry, adding rules for taking ground as well as overrunning with tanks. This makes for a much more fluid battlefield without adding too much in the complexity department. On the flip side...With all that it does right, Memoir still suffers from some the same problems as Borg's other C&C games. Killing units is usually the primary win condition, leading to wild attacks in the end game. There are also no rules for morale or battling back, making these hyper aggressive moves all the more rewarding. The command deck system falls apart a bit when applied to a more modern setting as well. Why is it that my troops don't fire back when assaulted? Were there really no radios in WWII? Then why can't I order the left flank?!? The unpredictability of the command deck combined with a lack of Ops fire, Cover fire, or any other modern combat tactics makes the WWII theme seem a little artificial.

 Memoir '44 has hit a rough spot in my collection. It's not deep enough to play with my gamer friends, but is a little too much for the wife and kids. (Not that my wife can't handle it, war games just hold no interest for her.) So for the most part, I break it out now and then (particularly when expansions hit...gotta catch 'em all!) get irritated with its idiosynchrocies, and put it away for a couple of months. Recently, I have been toying with some slight modifications, mostly imports from Battlelore and C&C Ancients. Put simply, Grenade hits are only counted in close assaults, and defending units who hold their ground in an assault get to battle back. Typically I abhorr house rules, but these seem to give the game a more tactical feel, with a little more risk involved when assaulting.

2/2010 - Traded for Tide of Iron.

6/2011 - Memoir '44 Online has brought me back into the fold. The ability to set up a game in a matter of minutes with no clean-up has refreshed my enjoyment of the game system. It's a VERY well-done implementation...Download it now!
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 9
What a pleasant surprise! I thought for sure I would hate this game, but it's one of the best I've ever played. I don't like dice in general, have often found line of sight to be infuriating Heroclix and am not crazy about war games. The line of sight is the most intuitive I've encountered (if not entirely realistic), the dice don't totally run the game, and it's SO MUCH FUN. This is one of those games that is much greater than the sum of its parts. Even things that would normally drive me crazy in games just left me smiling (for example, the second scenario features "air drop" reinforcements that involve dropping the plastic minis onto the board to see where they bounce to). I think a lot of this can be attributed to the short play time; my first game only took 45 minutes from opening the box to finish. Some of the scenarios seem to be unbalanced, but the game plays quickly enough that you could easily play both sides of it. I'd recommend anyone try this even if it's not their type of game, and I look forward to trying out the other C&C games.

RATING: 7
Not a bad LIGHT war game.  Although there's not much differentiation between nationalities (infantry is infantry, armor is armor), it's still pretty fun.  The card-based command system makes things interesting and frustrating all at once.  So, if you like rolling lots of dice and can live with the possibility of couple of good or bad card draws having a big effect on the game, give it a try.

Update:  My son (11 years old) has taken a keen interest in Memoir, so we've been playing a ton.  Still say it's a decent light war game.  I'm hoping this will serve as a springboard to meatier titles down the road (ASL!).  The many expansions do help provide a reasonable amount of differentiation between nationalities (although not quite so much with each country's units).

RATING: 8
I passed on this game for a long time because frankly it looked too light, too youngish.  But with the people on BGG singing its praises so loudly and so often, I had to look into it deeper.

I'm really glad that I did.  It's deceptively simple looking, but I think the versatility is great, as is the gameplay, the use of cards to order specific units, the quality of the components, and the sheer fun factor.

I also love that you can quickly play a scenario.  There are many times when I want to play a WWII wargame but don't have the time available for a long, drawnout battle.  Often, this solves the problem quite nicely.

Plus ... you get to play with army men!

RATING: 2
This game has a lot of things going for it, mainly the nice models and the speed of play. The dice mechanic doesn't make a ton of sense to me (why not just hit on 5+) but it does streamline play a bit if the rules got more complex. (I assume)

The cards (to me) really break the game. There is nearly zero balance in the cards (only slightly more then Battlelore which is somehow more broken than this game). It's highly possible through the course of a game you will move 20-30% more units than your opponent or that they will be unable to counter a move due to simply having no cards. I hate the mechanic that someone has just flat our better cards and I've won/lost games due to someone having several cards on a flank that could wipe out several units. It's totally possible to have a section fully outnumbered and out of position but then lose them due to no cards.

It's also possible (as mentioned before) to have a game where someone gets to move 20 units throughout the entire game and the other person moves 35 (it's happened, we tracked it for a game)

The dice don't bother me, that's a normal part of a wargame. The setup time, scenarios, models are all great. The cards fully break the game. As a solution in Memoir they attempted to add some drawing mechanics for the really crappy cards (draw two keep one) but it's just not enough. It's the equivilant of having multiple pistols in En Garde. The cards really need to be balanced. As is the cards are not situationally better, most cards are just flat out better than other cards under any situation.

This is compounded by the fact that under several scenarios there are not even certain unit types which makes several cards fully useless.

=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-
RATING: 6.25
I believe this title created a turning point in the development of wargames.  Because Memoir '44 was so approachable, and because of the short play time, a whole new fan base was created and made available for wargame designers.  

No longer were designers saddled with creating games for the spectacled, pocket-protected, introverted types.  They catapulted into the Dorito-munching, Mountain Dew slurping 'Wazzup' crowd.  Indeed, a tremendous leap forward.

What makes this title so appealing is the customizable board and endearing toy-soldier pieces.  Together, those two elements married nostalgia with swift, variable play.

This game also popularized card-driven games--no small feat.  Until Memoir '44, the card-driven mechanic wasn't embraced with open arms by the gaming public.  It is now dominating the industry.

Fun game.  Fast, sometimes furious action.  Limiting, though.  At times you feel as though your wrists (and brain) are shackled.  You see the battlefield, know where you need to attack or defend, and all you can do is lamely shuffle a few troops within a different area of the board.  

Frustrating at times, but I do enjoy pulling this out every so often.  It's easier to get non-gamers to say, "Yes" when they gaze upon a colorful, map-like battlefield hosting fantastic toy soldiers.  Oh, yeah.  :)

RATING: 8
Brilliant game - a complex and satisfying WWII tactical wargame playable in under an hour.  Want different scenarios? - the Memoir44 website offers a load of downloadable/printable scenarios for the basic game. Only 2 things let this game down; firstly the scenarios are unequal, so if you want 'fair' play you need to play a pair of games, one each side.  This could have been adjusted by a simple game mechanic of setting different victory flags for each side.  Secondly, the expansions are expensive and dont really live up to the original game, in particular being disappointing through the limited number of scenarios offered - I would have rated this game 9 otherwise, and little in the way of downloads last time I checked.  I was so pleased with this game that I ran a tournament in my games club.

RATING: 8
Memoir is a quick, fun, tactical board game.

I really enjoy that you can knock out battles fairly quickly and that the battles aren't necessarily balanced. Much like the history that they are based off of, certain battles favored one side... the question is... can you rewrite history? Because of this fact, it's best to play each scenario back-to-back with your opponent and then see who had the best aggregate score. Luckily, this isn't too difficult once you've set up the scenario for the first time.

Yes... there is quite a bit of luck based on card draws and die rolls. The fact that, at times, you can't seem to draw cards to save your life or that your plan of attack is flubbed by a seemingly easy die roll can be frustrating but the game as a whole makes up for those few frustrating times. You also have to realize that your opponent will more likely suffer the same fate at times too... so things generally balance out.

And while the game is great as a 1 vs 1 game with the one-off scenarios that are included in the base game, it really shines in the many types of "epic" games that you can play. I was fortunate enough to play the D-Day scenario at Gen Con 2014 and it was amazing. Not only was I taught the game by Richard Borg, seeing the game at that scale and playing with that many people was an experience I'll never forget. The addition of being able to use the campaign book to string together bunch of battles is pretty great too.

Recent plays have really made me appreciate the simplistic design and how it allows you to focus on strategy and tactics and doesn't get in the way of game play. Great game.
=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-=-

RATING: 10
[b]AWESOME TANK-BATTLING, MACHINEGUN-RATTLING, DICE-THROWING, LIGHT WARGAME![/b]

Fellow geekers, I have a confession, and it has been many moons since my last: I don't like ASL or any of the chit-moving, all-week-lasting, squad-level, WW2 wargames. My reasons are twofold: I don't like having to squint at chits with 15 numbers on the pale cheap-ass card representing a Panzer unit; plus, I really don't have the attention span to focus on one game for the days it seems to take to resolve a tank battle, like Stalingrad Operation Blue, set against the background of the snowy wastes of Russia, using a system that even details the armour of a KV-1 tank (75mm). Kudos to the designers for being so fastidious, but games like that are not my bag, nor ever will be. I'm interested in War World II, but that doesn't mean that I want to play a wargame on a poster-map, using an encyclopedia for the rules.

Give me a game that plays in a half-hour, lets myself and an eager opponent pit wits over the furious battles of WW2, and allows me to move hordes of plastic tanks about a battlefield to the clatter icon-dice, and I'm a happy bunny. M'44 is the game that fulfills those simple criteria.

One of the bright, shining jewels in my games collection, Memoir '44 was a real find for me - without BGG I would never have bought this game. I don't think that the back of the gamebox would have ever sold it to me - if I'd bothered to pick it up - and that is where the magic of the Geek sparkled like fairy dust all over this great game.
This has all the bits, bobs, and pieces that I loved about A&A; a WW2 theme enhanced by great all-round production values; a simple, solid ruleset, modified by terrain, etc; and the BEST set of dice to grace any game since Heroquest.

The scenarios are lop-sided, mostly, but that is all part of the game's charm. I WANT to fight against the odds, rushing my men into machine-gun nests, bring my tanks up to pound the guts out of the town hiding a bleedin' sniper, all the while taking an incredible beating from German artillery. That's how I want my quick-fire WW2 boardgames to play out. If I lose, I just play the scenario again, or swap sides and blast my friends to kingdom come. With a swift game like this, you have the chance to do such things.

BTW, I have always loved card-based mechanics, so their inclusion here is a work of inspired genius, bettered only by its younger sister, BattleLore.
Yes, the game is dependant on good dice-rolling and card drawing/playing. So bally what? War is all about luck, anyhow. Luck and planning. And in M'44, if you plan around what you're dealt, making the most of your options, take a few unlucky licks, you should trundle to victory more times than not. Stop whining, soldier, fight!

I will never turn down a game of this.

[i]AUG 2012 UPDATE:[/i]
This has been slightly usurped in my gaming court by [i]Napoleonics[/i] and [i]BattleLore.[/i]

RATING: 7
A good get-them-into-the-door style of games, especially for those interested in this type of theme.  The variable board seem to provide a good replayability in terms of the vast number of scenarios offered.  The only downside is that since it is card driven, you should be able to perform some kind of action with whatever you draw, but as the way Memoir '44 is conceived, it's way too easy to be screwed by cards that simply have no use to you.  As a result luck rules everything here.

RATING: 9
This is currently my big love (as of 12/07/22) and I've gone crazy obtaining all those expensive OOP expansions. All I'm missing is Tigers in the Snow and Hedgerow Hell (and the Campaign Bag) but I think I'll just give those a pass since the Equipment Pack is almost here. Love it to bits. It's simple enough that I can play it with my 7-year-old son and my 61-year-old father (who doesn't game) but still feels compelling and meaningful. Sure, there's a lot of randomness and luck involved but somehow I don't care at all that my ratio of wins to losses is something around 2-12. For a game I suck so badly at I still just can't get enough. Currently getting through the Campaigns in the Campaign book with the Mrs. Can't wait to get started on Overlord and Breakthrough format. We'll see if this earns a 10 or I get bored and lower the score.

Since I played it after C&C, however, it feels like a simplified version of the Roman game. There is no battle back, the leaders are conspicuously absent, and the cards feel overpowerful. I’ll likely play this more because the basics are still fun, but given the choice I will nearly always go with C&C: Ancients.

RATING: 6
3/15/07 - Man, this game really took a big nose dive on my respect-o-meter.  I played it a bunch when I first got it and thought it was rad.  Then it sat...and sat.  I finally broke it out again after a few years and found it to be aggravatingly unbalanced, scenario-wise, and entirely too simplistic.    There are a lot of 2 player games in the same category that operate on a much higher level - Dungeon Twister for one.

PS: I used to rate this game an 8.
----
I am the kind of dude who enjoys a complex game provided it's warranted.  I believe Memoir '44 is unqualifyable as complicated but is nevertheless one of the most enjoyable games I've ever played.
